THE TWO NOBLE KINSMEN Presented at the Blackfriers by the Kings Maiesties servants, with great applause: Written by the Worthies of their time; Mr. John Fletcher, and Mr. William Shakspeare. Gent. Printed at London by Tho. Cotes, for Iohn Waterson: and ate to be sold at the signe of the Crowne in Pauls Church-yard. 1634.

Play details
The two noble kinsmen. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1634. Date first performed: 1613-1614.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.l: NEw Plays, and Maidenheads, are near akin,
Much followed both, for both much money given,
If they stand sound, and well: And a good Play
(Whose modest Scenes blush on his marriage day,
And shake to loose his honour) is like her
That after holy Tie, and first nights stir
Yet still is Modesty, and still retains
More of the maid to sight, than Husbands pains;
We pray our Play may be so; For I am sure
It has a noble Breeder, and a pure,
A learned, and a Poet never went
More famous yet twixt Po and silver Trent
Chaucer (of all admired) the Story gives,
There constant to Eternity it lives;
If we let fall the Nobleness of this,
And the first sound this child hear, be a hiss,
How will it shake the bones of that good man,
And make him cry from under ground, O fan
From me the witless chaff of such a writer
That blasts my Bays, and my famed works makes lighter
Than Robin Hood? This is the fear we bring;
For to say Truth, it were an endless thing,
And too ambitious to aspire to him;
Weak as we are, and almost breathless swim
In this deep water. Do but you hold out
Your helping hands, and we shall take about,
And something do to save us: You shall hear
Scenes though below his Art, may yet appear
Worth two hours travel. To his bones sweet sleep:
Content to you. If this play do not keep,
A little dull time from us, we perceive
Our losses fall so thick, we must needs leave.

div2.head: Actus Primus.
div2.stage: Enter Hymen with a Torch burning: a Boy, in a white Robe before singing, and strewing Flowers: After Hymen, a Nymph, encompassed in her Tresses, bearing a wheaten Garland. Then Theseus between two other Nymphs with wheaten Chaplets on their heads. Then Hipolita the Bride, lead by Theseus, and another holding a Garland over her head (her Tresses likewise hanging.) After her Emilia holding up her Train.

sp.l: Music. Roses their sharpe spines being gone,
Not royal in their smells alone,
But in their hew.
Maiden Pinckes, of odour faint,
Daisies smellesse, yet most quaint
And sweet Time true.
Prim-rose first born, child of Ver,
Merry Spring times Harbinger,
With her bells dim.
Oxlips, in their Cradles growing,
Mary-golds, on death beds blowing,
Larkes-heeles trim.
All dear natures children: sweetly
fore Bride and Bridegrooms feet
Blessing their sense.
Not an angle of the air,
Bird melodious, or bird fair,
Is absent hence.
The Crow, the slanderous Cuckoo, nor
The boding Raven, nor Clough he
Nor chattering Pie,
May on our Bride-house perch or sing,
Or with them any discord bring
But from it fly.

div2.stage: Enter 3. Queens in Black, with veils stained, with imperiall Crowns. The 1. Queen falls down at the foot of Theseus; The 2. falls down at the foot of Hypolita. The 3. before Emilia.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: For pities sake and true gentilities,
Hear, and respect me.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: For your Mothers sake,
And as you wish your womb may thrive with fair ones,
Hear and respect me,

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: Now for the love of him whom Jove hath marked
The honour of your Bed, and for the sake
Of clear virginity, be Advocate
For us, and our distresses: This good deed
Shall raze you out of the Book of Trespasses
All you are set down there.

sp.speaker: Theseus.
sp.l: Sad Lady rise.

sp.speaker: Hypol.
sp.l: Stand up.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: No knees to me.
What woman I may steed that is distressed,
Does bind me to her.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: What is your request? Deliver you for all.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: We are three Queens, whose Sovereigns fell before
The wrath of cruel Creon; who endured
The Beaks of Ravens, Talents of the Knights,
And pecks of Crows, in the fowl fields of Thebs.
He will not suffer us to burn their bones,
To urn their ashes, nor to take the offence
Of mortal loathsomeness from the blessed eye
Of holy Phoebus, but infects the winds
With stench of our slain Lords. O pity Duke,
Thou purger of the earth, draw thy feared Sword
That does good turns to the world; give us the Bones
Of our dead Kings, that we may Chapel them;
And of thy boundless goodness take some note
Thatfor our crowned heads we have no roof,
Save this which is the Lions, and the Bears,
And vault to every thing.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Pray you kneel not,
I was transported with your Speech, and suffered
Your knees to wrong themselves; I have heard the fortunes
Of your dead Lords, which gives me such lamenting
As wakes my vengeance, and revenge for them .
King Capaneus, was your Lord the day
That he should marry you, at such a season,
As now it is with me, I met your Groom,
By Marsis Altar, you were that time fair;
Not Juno's Mantle fairer than your Tresses,
Nor in more bounty spread her. Your wheaten wreathe
Was then nor threshed, nor blasted; Fortune at you
Dimpled her Cheek with smiles: Hercules our kinsman
(Then weaker than your eyes) laid by his Club,
He tumbled down upon his Nenuan hide
And swore his sinews dewed: O grief, and time,
Fearful consumers, you will all devour.

sp.speaker: 1, Qu.
sp.l: O I hope some God,
Some God hath put his mercy in your manhood
Whereto he will infuse power, and press you forth
Our undertaker.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: O no knees, none Widow,
Unto the Helmeted-Belona use them,
And pray for me your Soldier.
Troubled I am.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: Honoured Hypolita
Most dreaded Amazonian, that hast slaine
The Sith-tuskd-Bore; that with thy Arm as strong
As it is white, wast near to make the male
To thy Sex captive; but that this thy Lord
Born to uphold Creation, in that honour
First nature styled it in, shrunk thee into
The bownd thou wast overflowing; at once subduing
That equally canst poise sternenes with pity,
Whom now I know hast much more power on him
than ever he had on thee, who owest his strength,
And his, Love too: who is a Servant for
The Tenor of the Speech. Dear Glass of Ladies
Bid him that we whom flaming war doth scorch,
Under the shadow of his Sword, may cool us:
Require him he advance it over our heads;
Speak it in a woman's key: like such a woman
As any of us three; weep ere you fail; lend us a knee;
But touch the ground for us no longer time
Than a Doves motion, when the head is plucked off:
Tell him if he in the blood sized field, lay swollen
Showing the Sun his Teeth; grinning at the Moon
What you would do.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Poor Lady, say no more:
I had as lief trace this good action with you
As that whereto I am going, and never yet
Went I so willing, way. My Lord is taken
Heart deep with your distress: Let him consider:
I will speak anon.

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: O my petition was
Set down in ice, which by hot grief uncandied
Melts into drops, so sorrow wanting form
Is pressed with deeper matter.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: Pray stand up,
Your grief is written in your cheek.

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: O woe,
You cannot read it there; there through my tears,
Like wrinkled pebbles in a glass stream
You may behold them (Lady, Lady, alack)
He that will all the Treasure know of the earth
Must know the Centre too; he that will fish
For my least minnow, let him lead his line
To catch one at my heart. O pardon me,
Extremity that sharpens sundry wits
Makes me a Fool.

sp.speaker: Emili.
sp.l: Pray you say nothing, pray you,
Who cannot feel, nor see the rain being in it,
Knows neither wet, nor dry, if that you were
The ground-piece of some Painter, I would buy you
To instruct me against a Capital grief indeed
Such heart pierced demonstration; but alas
Being a natural Sister of our Sex
Your sorrow beats so ardently upon me,
That it shall make a counter reflect against
My Brothers heart, and warm it to some pity
Though it were made of stone: pray have good comfort.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Forward to the Temple, leave not out a Jot
Of the sacred Ceremony.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: O This Celebration
Will long last, and be more costly than,
Your Suppliants war: Remember that your Fame
Knowles in the care, of the world: what you do quickly,
Is not done rashly; your first thought is more.
than others laboured meditance: your premeditating
More than their actions: But O Jove, your actions
Soon as they moves as As prays do the fish,
Subdue before they touch, think, dear Duke think
What beds our slain Kings have.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: What griefs our beds
That our dear Lords have none.

sp.speaker: 3, Qu.
sp.l: None fit for the dead:
Those that with Cords, Knives, drams precipitance,
Weary of this worlds light, have to themselves
Been deaths most horrid Agents, human grace
Affords them dust and shadow.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: But our Lords
Lie blistering fore the visitating Sun,
And were good Kings, when living.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: It is true. and I will give you comfort,
To give your dead Lords graves:
The which to do, must make some work with Creon;

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: And that work presents itself to the doing:
Now it will take form, the heats are gone tomorrow.
Then, bootless toil must recompense itself,
With its own sweat; Now he is secure,
Not dreams, we stand before your puissance
Wrenching our holy begging in our eyes
To make petition clear.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: Now you may take him,
Drunk with his victory.

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: And his Army full
Of Bread, and sloth.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Artesuis that best knowest
How to draw out fit to this enterprise,
The prim'st for this proceeding, and the number
To carry such a business, forth and levy
Our worthiest Instruments, whilst we despatch
This grand act of our life, this daring deed
Of Fate in wedlock.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: Dowagers,
take hands
Let us be Widows to our woes, delay
Commends us to a famishing hope.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: We come unseasonably: But when could grief
Cull forth as unpanged judgment can, fittest time
For best solicitation.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Why good Ladies,
This is a service, whereto I am going,
Greater than any was; it more imports me
Than all the actions that I have foregone,
Or futurely can cope.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: The more proclaiming
Our suit shall be neglected, when her Arms
Able to lock Jove from a Synod, shall
By warranting Moonlight corslet thee, O when
Her twining Cherries shall their sweetness fall
Upon thy tasteful lips, what wilt thou think
Of rotten Kings or blubbered Queens, what care
For what thou feelest not? what thou feelest being able
To make Mars spurn his Drom. O if thou couch
But one night with her, every hour in it will
Take hostage of thee for a hundred, and
Thou shalt remember nothing more, than what
That Banquet bids thee to.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Though much unlike
You should be so transported, as much sorry
I should be such a Suitor; yet I think
Did I not by the abstaining of my joy
Which breeds a deeper longing, cure their surfeit
That craves a present medicine, I should pluck
All Ladies scandal on me. Therefore Sir
As I shall here make trial of my prayers,
Either presuming them to have some force,
Or sentencing for ever their vigour dombe,
Prorogue this business, we are going about, and hang
Your Shield afore your Heart, about that neck
Which is my fee, and which I freely lend
To do these poor Queens service.

sp.speaker: All Queens.
sp.l: O help now
Our Cause cries for your knee.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: If you grant not
My Sister her petition in that force,
With that Celerity, and nature which
She makes it in: from henceforth I will not dare
To ask you any thing, nor be so hardy
Ever to take a Husband.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Pray stand up.
I am entreating of myself to do
That which you kneel to have me; Pyrithous
Lead on the Bride; get you and pray the Gods
For success, and return, omit not any thing
In the pretended Celebration : Queens
Follow your Soldier (as before) hence you
And at the banks of Anly meet us with
The forces you can raise, where we shall find
The moiety of a number, for a business,
More bigger looked; since that our Theme is haste
I stamp this kiss upon thy currant lip,
Sweet keep it as my Token; Set you forward
For I will see you gone.
Farewell my beauteous Sister: Pyrithous
Keep the feast full, bate not an hour on it.

sp.speaker: Pirithous.
sp.l: Sir
I will follow you at heels; The Feasts solemnity
Shall want till your return.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Cousin I charge you
Budge not from Athens; We shall be returning
Ere you can end this Feast; of which I pray you
Make no abatement; once more farewell all.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: Thus dost thou still make good the tongue of the

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: And earnest a Deity equal with Mars,

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: If not above him, for
Thou being but mortal makest affections bend
To Godlike honours; they themselves some say
Groan under such a Mastery.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: As we are men
Thus should we do, being sensually subdued
We loose our human title; good cheer Ladies.
Now turn we towards your Comforts.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: Dear Palamon, dearer in love than Blood
And our prime Cousin, yet unhardned in
The Crimes of nature; Let us leave the City
Thebs, and the temptings in it, before we further
Sully our gloss of youth,
And here to keep in abstinence we shame
As in Incontinence; for not to swim
In the aid of the Current, were almost to sink,
At least to frustrate striving, and to follow
The common Stream, it would bring us to an Eddy
Where we should turn or drown; if labour through,
Our gain but life, and weakness.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Your advice
Is cried up with example: what strange ruins
Since first we went to School, may we perceive
Walking in Thebs? Scars, and bare weeds
The gain of the Martialist, who did propound
To his bold ends, honour, and golden Ingots,
Which though he won, he had not, and now flirted
By peace for whom he fought, who then shall offer
When such I meet, and wish great Juno would
Resume her ancient fit of Jealousy
To get the Soldier work, that peace might purge
For her repletion, and retain anew
Her charitable heart now hard, and harsher
Than strife, or war could be.

sp.speaker: Arcite,
sp.l: Are you not out?
Meet you no ruin, but the Soldier in
The Cranks, and turns of Thebs? you did begin
As if you met decays of many kinds:
Perceive you none, that do arouse your pity
But the unconsidered Soldier?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes, I pity
Decays where ere I find them, but such most
That sweating in an honourable Toil
Are paid with ice to cool them .

sp.speaker: Arcite,
sp.l: It is not this
I did begin to speak of: This is virtue
Of no respect in Thebs, I spake of Thebs
How dangerous if we will keep our Honours,
It is for our residing, where every evil
Hath a good colour; where every seeming good is
A certain evil, where not to be even Jump
As they are, here were to be strangers, and
Such things to be mere Monsters.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: it is in our power,
(Unless we fear that Apes can tutor us ) to
Be Masters of our manners: what need I
Affect another's gate, which is not catching
Where there is faith, or to be fond upon
Another's way of speech, when by mine own
I may be reasonably conceived; saved too,
Speaking it truly; why am I bound
By any generous bond to follow him
Follows his Taylor, happily so long until
The followed, make pursuit? or let me know,
Why mine own Barber is unblessed, with him
My poor Chin too, for it is not Cizard just
To such a Favourites glass: What Cannon is there
That does command my Rapier from my hip
To danlge it in my hand, or to go tip toe
Before the street be foul? Either I am
The fore-horse in the Team, or I am none
That draw in the sequent trace: these poor sleight sores,
Need not a plantain; That which rips my bosom
Almost to the heart is,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: He,
A most unbounded Tyrant, whose successes
Makes heaven unfeard, and villainy assured
Beyond its power: there is nothing, almost puts
Faith in a fever, and deifies alone
Voluble chance, who only attributes
The faculties of other Instruments
To his own Nerves and act; Commands men service,
And what they win in it, boot and glory on;
That fears not to do harm; good, dares not; Let
The blood of mine that is sibbe to him, be sucked
From me with Leeches, Let them break and fall
Off me with that corruption.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Clear spirited Cozen
Let us leave his Court, that we may nothing share,
Of his loud infamy: for our milk,
Will relish of the pasture, and we must
Be vile, or disobedient, not his kinsmen
In blood, unless in quality.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Nothing truer:
I think the Echoes of his shames have deafened
The ears of heavenly Justice: widows cries
Descend again into their throats, and have not:
Due audience of the Gods: Valerius

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The King calls for you; yet be leaden footed
Till his great rage be off him. Phoebus when
He broke his whipstock and exclaimed against
The Horses of the Sun, but whispered too
The loudness of his Fury.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Small winds shake him,
But what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Theseus (who where he threats appals,) hath sent
Deadly defiance to him, and pronounces
Ruin to Thebs, who is at hand to seal
The promise of his wrath.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Let him approach;
But that we fear the Gods in him, he brings not
A jot of terror to us; Yet what man
Thirds his own worth (the case is each of ours)
When that his actions dregd, with mind assured
It is bad he goes about.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Leave that unreasoned.
Our services stand now for Thebs, not Creon,
Yet to be neutral to him, were dishonour;
Rebellious to oppose: therefore we must
With him stand to the mercy of our Fate,
Who hath bounded our last minute.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: So we must;
Is it said this wars a foot? or it shall be
On fail of some condition.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It is in motion
The intelligence of state came in the instant
With the defyer.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Let us to the king, who, were he
A quarter carrier of that honour, which
His Enemy come in, the blood we venture
Should be as for our health, which were not spent,
Rather laid out for purchase: but alas
Our hands advanced before our hearts, what will
The fall of the stroke do damage?

sp.speaker: Arci.
sp.l: Let the event,
That never erring Arbitrator, tell us
When we know all ourselves, and let us follow
The becking of our chance.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: No further.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sir farewell; repeat my wishes
To our great Lord, of whose success I dare not
Make any timorous question, yet I wish him
Excess, and overflow of power, if it might be
To endure ill-dealing fortune; speed to him,
Store never hurts good Governors.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: Though I know
His Ocean needs not my poor drops, yet they
Must yield their tribute there: My precious Maid,
Those best affections, that the heavens infuse
In their best tempered pieces, keep enthroned
In your dear heart.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Thanks Sir; Remember me
To our all royal Brother, for whose speed
The great Bellona I will solicit; and
Since in our terrene State petitions are not
Without gifts understood: I will offer to her
What I shall be advised she likes; our hearts
Are in his Army, in his Tent.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: In his bosom:
We have been Soldiers, and we cannot weep
When our Friends don their helms, or put to sea,
Or tell of Babes broached on the Lance, or women
That have sod their Infants in (and after eat them)
The brine, they wept at killing them ; Then if
You stay to see of us such Spinsters, we
Should hold you here for ever.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: Peace be to you
As I pursue this war, which shall be then
Beyond further requiring.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: How his longing
Follows his Friend; since his depart, his sports
Though craving seriousness, and skill, past slightly
His careless execution, where nor gain
Made him regard, or loss consider, but
Playing over business in his hand, another
Directing in his head, his mind, nurse equal
To these so differing Twins; have you observed him,
Since our great Lord departed?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: With much labour:
And I did love him for it they two have Cabined
In many as dangerous, as poor a Corner,
Peril and want contending, they have skiffed
Torrents whose roaring tyranny and power
In the least of these was dreadful, and they have
Fought out together, where Deaths-self was lodged,
Yet fate hath brought them off: Their knot of love
Tide, weaved, entangled, with so true, so long,
And with a finger of so deep a cunning
May be out worn, never undone. I think
Theseus cannot be umpire to himself
Cleaving his conscience into twain, and doing
Each side like Justice, which he loves best.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: There is a best, and reason has no manners
To say it is not you: I was acquainted
Once with a time, when I enjoyed a Play-fellow;
You were at wars, when she the grave enriched,
Who made too proud the Bed, took leave of the Moon
(which then looked pale at parting) when our count
Was each a eleven.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Yes
You talk of Pirithous and Theseus love;
Theirs has more ground, is more maturely seasoned,
More buckled with strong Judgment. and their needs
The one of the other may be said to water
sp.stage: 2. Hearses ready with Palamon: and Arcite: the 3. Queens. Theseus: and his Lords ready.
sp.l: Their intertangled roots of love, but I
And she (I sigh and spoke of) were things innocent,
Loved for we did, and like the Elements
That know not what, nor why, yet do effect
Rare issues by their appearance; our souls
Did so to one another; what she liked,
Was then of me approved, what not condemned
No more arraignment, the flower that I would pluck
And put between my breasts, O (then but beginning
To swell about the blossom) she would long
Till she had such another, and commit it
To the like innocent Cradle, where Phoenix like
They died in perfume: on my head no toy
But was her pattern, her affections (pretty
Though happily, her careless, were, I followed
For my most serious decking, had mine ear
Stolen some new air, or at adventure hummed on
From musical Coinage, why it was a note
Whereon her spirits would sojourn (rather dwell on)
And sing it in her slumbers; This rehearsal
(Which fury-innocent wots well) comes in
Like old importments bastard, has this end,
That the true love tween Maid, and maid, may be
More than in sex individual.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: you are out of breath
And this high speeded-pace, is but to say
That you shall never (like the Maid Flavina )
Love any that is called Man.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I am sure I shall not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Now alack weak Sister,
I must no more believe thee in this point
(Though, in it I know thou dost believe thyself, )
Then I will trust a sickly appetite,
That loathes even as it longs; but sure my Sister
If I were ripe for your persuasion, you
Have said enough to shake me from the Arm
Of the all noble Theseus, for whose fortunes,
I will now in, and kneel with great assurance,
That we, more than his Pirothous, possess
The high throne in his heart.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I am not against your faith,
Yet I continue mine.

div2.stage: A Battle struck within: Then a Retreat: Flourish. Then Enter Theseus (victor) the three Queens meet him, and fall on their faces before him.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: To thee no star be dark.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: Both heaven and earth
Friend thee for ever.

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: All the good that may
Be wished upon thy head, I cry Amen to it.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: the impartial Gods, who from the mounted
View us their mortal Heard, behold who err,
And in their time chastise: go and find out
The bones of your dead Lords, and honour them
With treble Ceremony, rather than a gap
Should be in their dear rights, we would supply it.
But those we will depute, which shall invest
You in your dignities, and even each thing
Our haste does leave imperfect; So adieu
And heavens good eyes look on you, what are those?

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: Men of great quality, as may be judged
By their appointment; Some of Thebs have told us
They are Sisters children, Nephews to the King.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: By the Helm of Mars, I saw them in the war,
Like to a pair of Lions, succoured with prey,
Make lanes in troops aghast. I fixed my note
Constantly on them; for they were a mark
Worth a god's view: what prisoner was it that told me
When I enquired their names?

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: We leave, they are called
Arcite and Palamon,

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: It is right, those, those
They are not dead?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Nor in a state of life, had they been taken
When their last hurts were given, it was possible
They might have been recovered; Yet they breathe
And have the name of men.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Then like men use them
The very lees of such (millions of rates)
Exceed the wine of others: all our Surgeons
Convent in their behoof, our richest balms
Rather than niggard waste, their lives concern us,
Much more than Thebs is worth, rather than have them
Freed of this plight, and in their morning state
(Sound and at liberty) I would them dead,
But forty thousand fold, we had rather have them
Prisoners to us, than death; Bear them speedily
From our kind air, to them unkind, and minister
What man to man may do for our sake more,
Since I have known frights, fury, friends, behests,
Loves, provocations, zeal, a mistress Task,
Desire of liberty, a fever, madness,
Hath set a mark which nature could not reach to
Without some imposition, sickness in will
Or wrestling strength in reason, for our Love
And great Appollos mercy, all our best,
Their best skill tender. Lead into the City,
Where having bound things scattered, we will post
To Athens for our Army.

div2.stage: Music. Enter the Queens with the Hearses of their Knights, in a Funeral Solemnity, &c.

sp.l: Urns, and odours, bring away,
Vapours, sighs, darken the day;
Our dole more deadly looks than dying
Balms, and Gums, and heavy cheers,
Sacred vials filled with tears,
And clamours through the wild air flying.
Come all sad, and solemn Shows,
That are quick-eyed pleasures foes;
We convent nought else but woes. We convent, et cetera.

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: This funeral path, brings to your households grave:
Joy seize on you again : peace sleep with him.

sp.speaker: 2. Qu.
sp.l: And this to yours.

sp.speaker: 1. Qu.
sp.l: Yours this way: Heavens lend
A thousand differing ways, to one sure end.

sp.speaker: 3. Qu.
sp.l: This world is a City full of straying Streets,
And Death is the market place, where each one meets.

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: I may depart with little, while I live, some thing I
May cast to you, not much: Alas the Prison I
Keep, though it be for great ones, yet they seldom
Come; Before one Salmon, you shall take a number
Of Minnows: I am given out to be better lined
Than it can appear, to me report is a true
Speaker: I would I were really, that I am
Delivered to be: Marry, what I have (be it what
it will) I will assure upon my daughter at
The day of my death.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Sir I demand no more than your own offer,
And I will estate your Daughter in what I
Have promised,

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: Well, we will talk more of this, when the solemnity
Is past; But have you a full promise of her?
When that shall be seen, I tender my consent.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I have Sir; here she comes.

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: Your Friend and I have chanced to name
You here, upon the old business: But no more of that.
Now, so soon as the Court hurry is over, we will
Have an end of it: In the mean time look tenderly
To the two Prisoners. I can tell you they are princes.

sp.speaker: Daug.
sp.l: These strewings are for their Chamber; it is pity they
Are in prison, and it were pity they should be out: I
Do think they have patience to make any adversity
Ashamed; the prison itself is proud of them ; and
They have all the world in their Chamber.

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: They are famed to be a pair of absolute men.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: By my troth, I think Fame but stammers them , they
Stand a greise above the reach of report.

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: I heard them reported in the Battle, to be the only doers.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Nay most likely, for they are noble sufferers; I
Marvel how they would have looked had they been
Victors, that with such a constant Nobility, enforce
A freedom out of Bondage, making misery their
Mirth, and affliction, a toy to jest at.

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: Do they so?

sp.speaker: Daug.
sp.l: It seems to me they have no more sense of their
Captivity, than I of ruling Athens: they eat
Well, look merrily, discourse of many things,
But nothing of their own restraint, and disasters:
Yet sometime a divided sigh, martyred as it were
In the deliverance, will break from one of them.
When the other presently gives it so sweet a rebuke,
That I could wish myself a Sigh to be so chid,
Or at least a Sigher to be comforted.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I never saw them.

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: The Duke himself came privately in the night,
And so did they, what the reason of it is, I
Know not: Look yonder they are; that is
Arcite looks out.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: No Sir, no, that is Palamon: Arcite is the
Lower of the twain; you may perceive a part
Of him.

sp.speaker: Iai.
sp.l: Go to leave your pointing; they would not
Make us their object; out of their sight.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: It is a holiday to look on them: Lord, the
Difference of men.

div2.stage: Enter Palamon, and Arcite in prison.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: How do you Noble Cousin?

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Why strong enough to laugh at misery,
And bear the chance of war yet, we are prisoners
I fear for ever Cousin.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: I believe it,
And to that destiny have patiently
Laid up my hour to come.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Where is Thebs now? where is our noble Country?
Where are our friends, and kindreds? never more
Must we behold those comforts, never see
The hardy youths strive for the Games of honour
(Hung with the painted favours of their Ladies)
Like tall Ships under sail: then start amongst them
And as an Eastwind leave them all behind us,
Like lazy Clouds, whilst Palamon and Arcite,
Even in the wagging of a wanton leg
Out-stripped the peoples praises, won the Garlands,
Ere they have time to wish them ours. O never
Shall we two exercise, like Twins of honour,
Our Arms again, and feel our fiery horses
Like proud Seas under us, our good Swords, now
(Better the red-eyed god of war never were)
Bravishd our sides, like age must run to rust,
And deck the Temples of those gods that hate us,
These hands shall never draw them out like lightning
To blast whole Armies more.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: Those hopes are Prisoners with us, here we are
And here the graces of our youths must wither
Like a too-timely Spring; here age must find us,
And which is heaviest ( Palamon ) unmarried,
The sweet embraces of a loving wife
Laden with kisses, armed with thousand Cupids
Shall never clasp our necks, no issue know us,
No figures of ourselves shall we ever see,
To glad our age, and like young Eagles teach them
Boldly to gaze against bright arms, and say
Remember what your fathers were, and conquer.
The fair-eyed Maids, shall weep our Banishment's,
And in their Songs, curse ever-blinded fortune
Till she for shame see what a wrong she has done
To youth and nature; This is all our world;
We shall know nothing here but one another,
Hear nothing but the Clock that tells our woes.
The Vine shall grow, but we shall never see it:
Summer shall come, and with her all delights;
But dead-cold winter must inhabit here still.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: It is too true Arcite. To our Theban hounds,
That shook the aged Forest with their echoes,
No more now must we halloo, no more shake
Our pointed Javelins, whilst the angry Swine
Flies like a parthian quiver from our rages,
Struck with our well-steeled Darts: All valiant uses,
(The food, and nourishment of noble minds,)
In us two here shall perish; we shall die
(which is the curse of honour) lastly,
Children of grief, and Ignorance.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Yet Cousin,
Even from the bottom of these miseries
From all that fortune can inflict upon us,
I see two comforts rising, two mere blessings,
If the gods please, to hold here a brave patience,
And the enjoying of our griefs together.
Whilst Palamon is with me, let me perish
If I think this our prison.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.l: Certainly,
It is a maine goodness Cousin, that our fortunes
Were twined together; it is most true, two souls
Put in two noble Bodies, let them suffer
The gaul of hazard, so they grow together,
Will never sink, they must not, say they could,
A willing man dies sleeping, and all is done.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Shall we make worthy uses of this place
That all men hate so much?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: How gentle Cousin?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Let us think this prison, holy sanctuary,
To keep us from corruption of worse men,
We are young and yet desire the ways of honour,
That liberty and common Conversation
The poison of pure spirits; might like women
Woo us to wander from. What worthy blessing
Can be but our Imaginations
May make it ours? And here being thus together,
We are an endless mine to one another;
We are one another's wife, ever begetting
New births of love; we are father, friends, acquaintance,
We are in one another, Families,
I am your heir, and you are mine: This place
Is our Inheritance: no hard Oppressor
Dare take this from us; here with a little patience
We shall live long, and loving: No surfeits seek us:
The hand of war hurts none here, nor the Seas
Swallow their youth: were we at liberty,
A wife might part us lawfully, or business,
Quarrels consume us, Envy of ill men
Crave our acquaintance, I might sicken Cousin,
Where you should never know it, and so perish
Without your noble hand to close mine eyes,
Or prayers to the gods; a thousand chances
Were we from hence, would sever us.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You have made me
(I thank you Cousin Arcite ) almost wanton
With my Captivity: what a misery
It is to live abroad? and every where:
It is like a Beast methinks: I find the Court here,
I am sure a more content, and all those pleasures
That woo the wills of men to vanity,
I see through now, and am sufficient
To tell the world, it is but a gaudy shadow,
That old Time, as he passes by takes with him,
What had we been old in the Court of Creon,
Where sin is Justice, lust, and ignorance,
The virtues of the great ones: Cousin Arcite,
Had not the loving gods found this place for us
We had died as they do, ill old men, unwept,
And had their Epitaphs, the peoples Curses,
Shall I say more?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I would hear you still.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Ye shall.
Is there record of any two that loved
Better than we do Arcite?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sure there cannot.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I do not think it possible our friendship
Should ever leave us.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Till our deaths it cannot
And after death our spirits shall be led
To those that love eternally. Speak on Sir.
This garden has a world of pleasures in it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: What Flower is this?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: It is called Narcissus Madam.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: That was a fair Boy certain, but a fool,
To love himself, were there not maids enough?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Pray forward.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Or were they all hard hearted?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: They could not be to one so fair.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Thou wouldst not.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I think I should not, Madam.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: That is a good wench:
But take heed to your kindness though.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Why Madam?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Men are mad things.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: Will ye go forward Cousin?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Canst not thou work: such flowers in silk wench?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I will have a gown full of them and of these,
This is a pretty colour, wilt not do
Rarely upon a Skirt wench?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Dainty Madam.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Cousin, Cousin, how do you Sir? Why Palamon?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Never till now I was in prison Arcite.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why what is the matter Man?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Behold, and wonder.
By heaven she is a Goddess.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Do reverence.
She is a Goddess Arcite.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Of all Flowers.
Methinks a Rose is best.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Why gentle Madam?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: It is the very Emblem of a Maid.
For when the west wind courts her gently
How modestly she blows, and paints the Sun,
With her chaste blushes? When the North comes near her,
Rude and impatient, then, like Chastity
She locks her beauties in her bud again,
And leaves him to base briers.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: Yet good Madam,
Sometimes her modesty will blow so far
She falls for it: a Maid
If she have any honour, would be loath
To take example by her.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Thou art wanton.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: She is wondrous fair.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: She is all the beauty extant.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: The Sun grows high, let us walk in, keep these flowers,
We will see how near Art can come near their colours;
I am wondrous merry hearted, I could laugh now.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: I could lie down I am sure.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: And take one with you?

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.l: That is as we bargain Madam,

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Well, agree then.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What think you of this beauty?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: It is a rare one.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Is it but a rare one?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Yes a matchless beauty.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Might not a man well lose himself and love her?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I cannot tell what you have done, I have,
Beshrew mine eyes for it, now I feel my Shackles.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You love her then?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Who would not?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And desire her?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Be fore my liberty.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I saw her first.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: That is nothing

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: But it shall be.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I saw her too.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes, but you must not love her.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I will not as you do; to worship her;
As she is heavenly, and a blessed Goddess;
(I love her as a woman, to enjoy her)
So both may love.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You shall not love at all.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not love at all.
Who shall deny me?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I that first saw her; I that took possession
First with mine eye of all those beauties
In her revealed to mankind: if thou lovest her.
Or entertainest a hope to blast my wishes,
Thou art a Traitor Arcite and a fellow
False as thy Title to her: friendship, blood
And all the ties between us I disclaim
If thou once think upon her.

sp.speaker: Arc,
sp.l: Yes I love her,
And if the lives of all my name lay on it,
I must do so, I love her with my soul,
If that will lose ye, farewell Palamon,
I say again, I love, and in loving her maintain
I am as worthy, and as free a lover
And have as just a title to her beauty
As any Palamon or any living
That is a man's Son.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Have I called thee friend?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Yes, and have found me so; why are you moved thus?
Let me deal coldly with you, am not I
Part of you blood, part of your soul? you have told me
That I was Palamon, and you were Arcite.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Am not I liable to those affections,
Those joys, griefs, angers, fears, my friend shall suffer?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Ye may be.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why then would you deal so cunningly,
So strangely, so unlike a noble kinsman
To love alone? speak truly, do you think me
Unworthy of her sight?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: No, but unjust,
If thou pursue that sight.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Because an other
First sees the Enemy, shall I stand still
And let mine honour down, and never charge?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes, if he be but one.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: But say that one
Had rather combat me?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Let that one say so,
And use thy freedom: else if thou pursuest her,
Be as that cursed man that hates his Country,
A branded villain.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You are mad.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I must be.
Till thou art worthy, Arcite, it concerns me,
And in this madness, if I hazard thee
And take thy life, I deal but truly.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Fie Sir.
You play the Child extremely: I will love her,
I must, I ought to do so, and I dare,
And all this justly.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: O that now, that now
Thy false-self and thy friend, had but this fortune
To be one hour at liberty, and grasp
Our good Swords in our hands, I would quickly teach thee
What it were to filch affection from another:
Thou art baser in it than a Cut purse;
Put but thy head out of this window more,
And as I have a soul, I will nail thy life to it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Thou darest not fool, thou canst not, thou art feeble.
Put my head out? I will throw my Body out,
And leap the garden, when I see her next
And pitch between her arms to anger thee.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: No more; the keeper is coming; I shall live
To knock thy brains out with my Shackles.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: By your leave Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Pala.
sp.l: Now honest keeper?

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: Lord Arcite, you must presently to the Duke;
The cause I know not yet.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am ready keeper.

sp.speaker: Keeper,
sp.l: Prince Palamon, I must awhile bereave you
Of your fair Cousins Company.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And me too,
Even when you please of life; why is he sent for?
It may be he shall marry her, he is goodly,
And like enough the Duke hath taken notice
Both of his blood and body: But his falsehood,
Why should a friend be treacherous? If that
Get him a wife so noble, and so fair;
Let honest men never love again. Once more
I would but see this fair One: Blessed Garden,
And fruit, and flowers more blessed that still blossom
As her bright eyes shine on ye. would I were
For all the fortune of my life hereafter
Yon little Tree, yon blooming Apricot;
How I would spread, and fling my wanton arms
In at her window; I would bring her fruit
Fit for the Gods to feed on: youth and pleasure
Still as she tasted should be doubled on her,
And if she be not heavenly I would make her
So near the Gods in nature, they should fear her.
And then I am sure she would love me: how now keeper

sp.speaker: Keeper,
sp.l: Banished: Prince Pirithous
Obtained his liberty; but never more
Upon his oath and life must he set foot
Upon this Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: He is a blessed man,
He shall see Thebs again, and call to Arms
The bold young men, that when he bids them charge,
Fall on like fire: Arcite shall have a Fortune,
If he dare make himself a worthy Lover,
Yet in the Field to strike a battle for her;
And if he lose her then, he is a cold Coward;
How bravely may he bear himself to win her
If he be noble Arcite; thousand ways.
Were I at liberty, I would do things
Of such a virtuous greatness, that this Lady,
This blushing virgin should take manhood to her
And seek to ravish me.

sp.speaker: Keeper
sp.l: My Lord for you
I have this charge too.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: To discharge my life.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: No, but from this place to remove your Lordship,
The windows are too open.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Devils take them
That are so envious to me; prithee kill me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: And hang for it afterward.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: By this good light
Had I a sword I would kill thee.

sp.speaker: Keep,
sp.l: Why my Lord?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Thou bringest such pelting scurvy news continually
Thou art not worthy life; I will not go.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Indeed you must my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: May I see the garden?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then I am resolved, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I must constrain you then: and for you are dangerous
I will clap more irons on you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Do good keeper.
I will shake them so, ye shall not sleep,
I will make ye a new Morris, must I go?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Farewell kind window.
May rude wind never hurt thee. O my Lady
If ever thou hast felt what sorrow was,
Dream how I suffer. Come; now bury me.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: Banished the kingdom? it is a benefit,
A mercy I must thank them for, but banished
The free enjoying of that face I die for,
O it was a studied punishment, a death
Beyond Imagination: Such a vengeance
That were I old and wicked, all my sins
Could never pluck upon me. Palamon;
Thou hast the Start now, thou shalt stay and see
Her bright eyes break each morning against thy window,
And let in life into thee; thou shalt feed
Upon the sweetness of a noble beauty,
That nature never exceeded, nor never shall:
Good gods? what happiness has Palamon?
Twenty to one, he will come to speak to her,
And if she be as gentle, as she is fair,
I know she is his, he has a Tongue will tame
Tempests, and make the wild Rocks wanton. Come what can come,
The worst is death; I will not leave the Kingdom,
I know mine own, is but a heap of ruins,
And no redress there, if I go, he has her.
I am resolved an other shape shall make me,
Or end my fortunes. Either way, I am happy:
I will see her, and be near her, or no more.

div2.stage: Enter 4. Country people, & one with a garland before them.

sp.l: My Masters, I will be there that is certain.
And I will be there.
And I.
Why then have with ye Boys; It is but a chiding,
Let the plough play today, I will tickle it out
Of the Jades tails tomorrow.
I am sure
To have my wife as jealous as a Turkey:
But that is all one, I will go through, let her mumble.
Clap her aboard tomorrow night, and stow her,
And all is made up again.
Aye, do but put a feskne in her fist, and you shall see her
Take a new lesson out, and be a good wench.
do we all hold, against the Maying?
Hold? what should ail us?
Arcas will be there.
And Sennois.
And Rycas, and three better lads never danced under green Tree,
And yet know what wenches: ha?
But will the dainty Dominie, the Schoolmaster keep touch
Do you think: for he does all ye know.

sp.p:
He will eat a hornebooke ere he fail: go to, the matter is
too far driven between him, and the Tanners daughter,
to let slip now, and she must see the
Duke, and she must
dance too.

sp.l: Shall we be lusty.

sp.p:
All the Boys in Athens blow wind in the breech on us
and here I will be and there I will be, for our Town, and here
again, and there again : ha, Boys, heigh for the weavers.

sp.l: This must be done in the woods.
O pardon me.

sp.p:
By any means our thing of learning sees so: where he
himself will edify the Duke most parlously in our behalves:
he is excellent in the woods, bring him to the plains, his learning
makes no cry.

sp.l: We will see the sports, then every man to his Tackle: and
Sweet Companions let us rehearse by any means, before
The Ladies see us, and do sweetly, and God knows what
May come of it.
Content; the sports once ended, we will perform. Away
Boys and hold.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p:
By your leaves honest friends: pray you whither
go you.

sp.l: Whither? why, what a question is that?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Yes, it is a question, to me that know not.
To the Games my Friend.
Where were you bred you know it not?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not far Sir,
Are there such Games today?
Yes marry are there:
And such as you never saw; The Duke himself
Will be in person there.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: What pastimes are they?
Wrestling, and Running; It is a pretty Fellow.
Thou wilt not go along.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not yet Sir.
Well Sir
Take your own time, come Boys
My mind misgives me
This fellow has a vengeance trick on the hip,
Mark how his body is made for it.
I will be hanged though
If he dare venture, hang him plumb porridge,
He wrestle? he roast eggs. Come let us be gone Lads.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: This is an offered opportunity
I durst not wish for. Well, I could have wrestled,
The best men called it excellent, and run
Swifter, than wind upon a field of Corn
(Curling the wealthy ears) never flew: I will venture,
And in some poor disguise be there, who knows
Whether my brows may not be girt with garlands?
And happiness prefer me to a place,
Where I may ever dwell in sight of her.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Why should I love this Gentleman? It is odds
He never will affect me; I am base,
My Father the mean Keeper of his Prison,
And he a prince; To marry him is hopeless;
To be his whore, is witless; Out upon it;
What pushes are we wenches driven to
When fifteen once has found us? First I saw him,
I (seeing) thought he was a goodly man;
He has as much to please a woman in him,
(If he please to bestow it so) as ever
These eyes yet looked on; Next, I pitied him,
And so would any young wench on my Conscience
That ever dreamed, or vowed her Maidenhead
To a young hansom Man; Then I loved him,
(Extremely loved him) infinitely loved him;
And yet he had a Cousin, fair as he too.
But in my heart was Palamon, and there
Lord, what a coil he keeps? To hear him
Sing in an evening, what a heaven it is?
And yet his Songs are sad-ones; Fairer spoken,
Was never Gentleman. When I come in
To bring him water in a morning, first
He bows his noble body, then salutes me, thus:
Fair, gentle Maid, good morrow, may thy goodness,
Get thee a happy husband; Once he kissed me,
I loved my lips the better ten days after,
Would he would do so every day; He grieves much,
And me as much to see his misery.
What should I do, to make him know I love him,
For I would fain enjoy him? Say I ventured
To set him free? what says the law then? Thus much
For Law, or kindred: I will do it,
And this night, or tomorrow he shall love me.

div2.stage: Enter Theseus, Hipolita, Pirithous, Emilia: Arcite with a Garland, &c. This short flourish of Cornets and Shouts within.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You have done worthily; I have not seen
Since Hercules, a man of tougher sinews;
What ere you are, you run the best, and wrestle,
That these times can allow.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: I am proud to please you.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: What Country bred you?

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: This; but far off, Prince.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Are you a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: My father said so;
And to those gentle uses gave me life.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Are you his heir?

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: His youngest Sir.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Your Father
Sure is a happy Sire then: what proves you?

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: A little of all noble Qualities:
I could have kept a Hawk, and well have holloa'd
To a deep cry of Dogs; I dare not praise
My feat in horsemanship: yet they that knew me
Would say it was my best piece: last, and greatest,
I would be thought a Soldier.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You are perfect.

sp.speaker: Pirith.
sp.l: Upon my soul, a proper man.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: He is so.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How do you like him Lady?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I admire him,
I have not seen so young a man, so noble
(If he say true,) of his sort.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Believe,
His mother was a wondrous handsome woman,
His face methinks, goes that way.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: But his Body
And fiery mind, illustrate a brave Father.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mark how his virtue, like a hidden Sun
Breaks through his baser garments.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: He is well got sure.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: What made you seek this place Sir?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Noble Theseus.
To purchase name, and do my ablest service
To such a well-found wonder, as thy worth,
For only in thy Court, of all the world
dwells faire-eyd honour.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: All his words are worthy.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Sir, we are much indebted to your travel,
Nor shall you loose your wish: Perithous
Dispose of this fair Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Perith.
sp.l: What ere you are you are mine, and I shall give you
To a most noble service, to this Lady,
This bright young Virgin; pray observe her goodness;
You have honoured her fair birth-day, with your virtues,
And as your due you are hers: kiss her fair hand Sir.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, you are a noble Giver: dearest Beauty,
Thus let me seal my vowed faith: when your Servant
(Your most unworthy Creature) but offends you,
Command him die, he shall.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: That were too cruel.
If you deserve well Sir; I shall soon see it:
You are mine, and somewhat better than your rank I will use you.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I will see you furnished, and because you say
You are a horseman, I must needs entreat you
This afternoon to ride, but it is a rough one.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I like him better (Prince) I shall not then
Freeze in my Saddle.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Sweet, you must be ready,
And you Emilia, and you (Friend) and all
Tomorrow by the Sun, to do observance
To flowery May, in Dians wood: wait well Sir
Upon your Mistress: Emily, I hope
He shall not go a foot.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: That were a shame Sir,
While I have horses: take your choice, and what
You want at any time, let me but know it;
If you serve faithfully, I dare assure you
You will find a loving Mistress.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If I do not,
Let me find that my Father ever hated,
Disgrace, and blows.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Go lead the way; you have won it:
It shall be so; you shall receive all dues
Fit for the honour you have won; It were wrong else,
Sister, beshrew my heart, you have a Servant,
That if I were a woman, would be Master,
But you are wise.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I hope too wise for that Sir.

sp.speaker: Daughter.
sp.l: Let all the Dukes, and all the devils roar,
He is at liberty: I have ventured for him,
And out I have brought him to a little wood
A mile hence, I have sent him, where a Cedar
Higher than all the rest, spreads like a plane
Till I provide him Files, and food, for yet
His iron bracelets are not off. O Love
What a stout hearted child thou art! My Father
Durst better have endured cold iron, than done it:
I love him, beyond love, and beyond reason,
Or wit, or safety: I have made him know it
I care not, I am desperate, If the law
Find me, and then condemn me for it; some wenches,
Some honest hearted Maids, will sing my Dirge.
And tell to memory, my death was noble,
Dying almost a Martyr: That way he takes,
I purpose is my way too: Sure he cannot
Be so unmanly, as to leave me here,
If he do, Maids will not so easily
Trust men again : And yet he has not thanked me
For what I have done: no not so much as kissed me,
And that ( methinks ) is not so well; nor scarcely
Could I persuade him to become a Freeman,
He made such scruples of the wrong he did
To me, and to my Father. Yet I hope
When he considers more, this love of mine
Will take more root within him: Let him do
What he will with me, so he use me kindly,
For use me so he shall, or I will proclaim him
And to his face, no-man: I will presently
Provide him necessaries, and pack my clothes up,
And where there is a path of ground I will venture
So he be with me; By him, like a shadow
I will ever dwell; within this hour the whoobub
Will be all over the prison: I am then
Kissing the man they look for: farewell Father;
Get many more such prisoners, and such daughters,
And shortly you may keep yourself. Now to him:

div2.stage: Cornets in sundry places, Noise and hallowing as people a Maying.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: The Duke has lost Hypolita; each took
A several land. This is a solemn Right
They owe bloomed May, and the Athenians pay it
To the heart of Ceremony: O Queen Emilia
Fresher than May, sweeter
Than her gold Buttons on the bows, or all
the enamelled knacks of the Mead, or garden, yea
(We challenge too) the bank of any Nymph
That makes the stream seem flowers; thou o Jewel
Of the wood, of the world, hast likewise blessed a pace
With thy sole presence, in thy rumination
That I poor man might eftsoons come between
And chop on some cold thought, thrice blessed chance
To drop on such a Mistress, expectation
most guiltless on it: tell me O Lady Fortune
(Next after Emily my Sovereign) how far
I may be proud. She takes strong note of me,
Hath made me near her; and this beauteous Morn
(The prim'st of all the year) presents me with
A brace of horses, two such Steeds might well
Be by a pair of Kings backed, in a Field
That their crowns titles tried: Alas, alas
Poor Cousin Palamon, poor prisoner, thou
So little dreamest upon my fortune, that
Thou thinkst thyself, the happier thing, to be
So near Emilia, me thou deemest at Thebs,
And therein wretched, although free; But if
Thou knewest my Mistress breathed on me, and that
I eared her language, lived in her eye; O Cuz
What passion would enclose thee.

div2.stage: Enter Palamon as out of a Bush, with his Shackles: bends his fist at Arcite.

sp.speaker: Palamon.
sp.l: Traitor kinsman,
Thou shouldst perceive my passion, if these signs
Of prisonment were off me, and this hand
But owner of a Sword: By all oaths in one
I, and the justice of my love would make thee
A confessed Traitor, o thou most perfidious
That ever gently looked the voids of honour.
That ever bore gentle Token; falsest Cousin
That ever blood made kin, call'st thou her thine?
I will prove it in my Shackles, with these hands,
Void of appointment, that thou liest, and art
A very thief in love, a Chaffy Lord
Nor worth the name of villain: had I a Sword
And these house clogs away.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Cozener Arcite, give me language, such
As thou hast showed me feat.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not finding in
The circuit of my breast, any gross stuff
To form me like your blazon, holds me to
This gentleness of answer; it is your passion
That thus mistakes, the which to you being enemy,
Cannot to me be kind: honour, and honesty
I cherish, and depend on, how soever
You skip them in me, and with them fair Cuz
I will maintain my proceedings; pray be pleased
To show in generous terms, your griefs, since that
Your question is with your equal, who professes
To clear his own way, with the mind and Sword
Of a true Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: That thou durst Arcite.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: My Cuz, my Cuz, you have been well advertised
How much I dare, you have seen me use my Sword
Against the advice of fear: sure of another
You would not hear me doubted, but your silence
Should break out, though in the Sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Sir,
I have seen you move in such a place, which well
Might justify your manhood, you were called
A good knight and a bold; But the whole week is not fair
If any day it rain: Their valiant temper
Men loose when they incline to treachery,
And then they fight like compelled Bears, would fly
Were they not tide.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Kinsman; you might as well
Speak this, and act it in your Glass, as to
His ear, which now disdains you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Come up to me,
Quit me of these cold Gyves, give me a Sword
Though it be rusty, and the charity
Of one meal lend me; Come before me then
A good Sword in thy hand, and do but say
That Emily is thine, I will forgive
The trespass thou hast done me, yea my life
If then thou carry it, and brave souls in shades
That have died manly, which will seek of me
Some news from earth, they shall get none but this
That thou art brave, and noble.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Be content,
Again betake you to your hawthorn house,
With counsel of the night, I will be here
With wholesome viands; these impediments
Will I file off, you shall have garments, and
Perfumes to kill the smell of the prison, after
When you shall stretch yourself, and say but Arcite
I am in plight, there shall be at your choice
Both Sword, and Armour.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: O you heavens, dares any
So noble bear a guilty business! none
But only Arcite, therefore none but Arcite
In this kind is so bold.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I do embrace you, and your offer, for
Your offer do it I only, Sir your person
Without hypocrisy I may not wish
More than my Swords edge on it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You hear the Horns;
Enter your Music least this match between us
Be crossed, ere met, give me your hand, farewell.
I will bring you every needful thing: I pray you
Take comfort and be strong.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Pray hold your promise;
And do the deed with a bent brow, most certain
You love me not, be rough with me, and pour
This oil out of your language; by this air
I could for each word, give a Cuff: my stomach
not reconciled by reason,

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Plainly spoken,
Yet pardon me hard language, when I spur
My horse, I chide him not; content, and anger
In me have but one face. Hark Sir, they call
The scattered to the Banquet; you must guess
I have an office there.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Sir your attendance
Cannot please heaven, and I know your office
Unjustly is achieved.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If a good title,
I am persuaded this question sick between us,
By bleeding must be cured. I am a Suitor,
That to your Sword you will bequeath this plea,
And talk of it no more.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: But this one word:
You are going now to gaze upon my Mistress,
For note you, mine she is.

sp.speaker: Arc,
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Nay pray you,
You talk of feeding me to breed me strength
You are going now to look upon a Sun
That strengthens what it looks on, there
You have a vantage over me, but enjoy it till
I may enforce my remedy. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: He has mistook; the Beak I meant, is gone
After his fancy, It is now well-nigh morning,
No matter, would it were perpetual night,
And darkness Lord of the world, Hark it is a wolf:
In me hath grief slain fear, and but for one thing
I care for nothing, and that is Palamon.
I wreak not if the wolves would jaw me, so
He had this File; what if I hallowed for him?
I cannot hallow: if I whooped; what then?
If he not answered, I should call a wolf,
And do him but that service. I have heard
Strange howls this live-long night, why may it not be
They have made prey of him? he has no weapons,
He cannot run, the Jangling of his Gives
Might call fell things to listen, who have in them
A sense to know a man unarmed, and can
Smell where resistance is. I will set it down
He is torn to pieces, they hold many together
And then they feed on him: So much for that,
Be bold to ring the Bell; how stand I then?
All is charred when he is gone, No, no I lie,
My Father is to be hanged for his escape,
Myself to beg, if I prized life so much
As to deny my act, but that I would not,
Should I try death by dussons: I am mop't,
Food took I none these two days.
Sipped some water. I have not closed mine eyes
Save when my lids scoured off their bine; alas
Dissolve my life, Let not my sense unsettle
Lest I should drown, or stab, or hang myself.
O state of Nature, fail together in me,
Since thy best props are warped: So which way now?
The best way is, the next way to a grave:
Each errant step beside is torment. Lo
The Moon is down, the Crickets chirp, the Screech-owl
Calls in the dawn; all offices are done
Save what I fail in: But the point is this
An end, and that is all.

div2.stage: Enter Arcite, with Meat, Wine, and Files.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I should be near the place, hoa. Cousin Palamon.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: The same: I have brought you food and files,
Come forth and fear not, here is no Theseus.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Not none so honest Arcite.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: That is no matter,
We will argue that hereafter: Come take courage,
You shall not die thus beastly, here Sir drink
I know you are faint, then I will talk further with you

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Arcite, thou mightst now poison me.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I might.
But I must fear you first: Sit down, and good now
No more of these vain parleys; let us not
Having our ancient reputation with us
Make talk for Fools, and Cowards, To your health, et cetera.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Pray sit down then, and let me entreat you
By all the honesty and honour in you,
No mention of this woman, it will disturb us,
We shall have time enough.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Well Sir, I will pledge you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Drink a good hearty draught, it breeds good blood man.
Do not you feel it thaw you?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Stay, I will tell you after a draught or two more.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Spare it not, the Duke has more Cuz: Eat now.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am glad you have so good a stomach.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I am gladder I have so good meat to it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Is it not mad lodging, here in the wild woods Cousin

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes, for them that have wild Consciences.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: How tastes your victuals? your hunger needs no sauce I see,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Not much.
But if it did, yours is too tart: sweet Cousin: what is this?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Venison.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: It is a lusty meat:
Give me more wine; here Arcite to the wenches
We have known in our days. The Lord Stewards daughter.
do you remember her?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: After you Cuz.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: She loved a black-haired man.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: She did so; well Sir.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And I have heard some call him Arcite. and

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Out with it faith.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: She met him in an Arbour:
What did she there Cuz? play on the virginals?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Something she did Sir.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Made her groan a month for it; or two or three or ten

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: The Marshals Sister,
Had her share too, as I remember Cousin,
Else there be tales abroad, you will pledge her?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: A pretty brown wench it is ~~ There was a time
When young men went a hunting, and a wood,
And a broad Beech: and thereby hangs a tale: heigh ho.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: For Emily, upon my life; Fool
Away with this strained mirth; I say again
That sigh was breathed for Emily; base Cousin,
Darest thou break first?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: you are wide.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: By heaven and earth, there is nothing in thee honest.

sp.speaker: Arc,
sp.l: Then I will leave you: you are a Beast now:

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: As thou makest me, Traitor.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: There is all things needful, files and shirts, and, perfumes:
I will come again some two hours hence, and bring
That that shall quiet all,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: A Sword and Armour.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Fear me not; you are now too foul; farewell.
Get off your Trinkets, you shall want nought;

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Sir ha:

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I will hear no more.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: If he keep touch, he dies for it.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I am very cold, and all the Stars are out too,
The little Stars, and all, that look like eaglets:
The Sun has seen my Folly: Palamon;
Alas no; he is in heaven; where am I now?
Yonder is the sea, and there is a Ship; how it tumbles
And there is a Rock lies watching under water;
Now, now, it beats upon it; now, now, now,
There is a leak sprung, a sound one, how they cry?
Upon her before the wind, you will loose all else:
Up with a course or two, and take about Boys.
Good night, good night, you are gone; I am very hungry,
Would I could find a fine Frog; he would tell me
News from all parts of the world, then would I make
A Carecke of a Cockle shell, and sail
By east and North East to the King of Pygmies,
For he tells fortunes rarely. Now my Father
Twenty to one is trust up in a trice
Tomorrow morning, I will say never a word.
For I will cut my green coat, afoot above my knee,
And I will clip my yellow locks; an inch below mine eye.
hey, nonny, nonny, nonny,
He is buy me a white Cut, forth for to ride
And I will go seek him, throw the world that is so wide
hey nonny, nonny, nonny.
O for a prick now like a Nightingale, to put my breast
Against. I shall sleep like a Top else.

div2.stage: Enter a School master 4. Countrymen: and Baum. 2. or 3 wenches, with a Taborer.

sp.speaker: Sch
sp.p:
Fie, fie, what tediosity, and disensanity is here among ye?
have my Rudiments been laboured so long with ye? milked unto
ye, and by a figure even the very plumbroth and marrow of
my understanding laid upon ye? and do you still cry where,
and how, and wherefore? you most course freeze capacities, ye
gave Judgments, have I said thus let be, and there let be,
and then let be, and no man understand me, proh deum,
medius fidius, ye are all dunces: For why here stand I.
Here the Duke comes, there are you close in the Thicket; the
Duke appears, I meet him and unto him I utter learned
things, and many figures, he hears, and nods, and hums, and
then cries rare, and I go forward, at length I fling my Cap
up; mark there; then do you as once did Meleager, and the
Bore break comely out before him: like true lovers, cast yourselves
in a Body decently, and sweetly, by a figure trace, and
turn Boys.

sp.l: And sweetly we will do it Master Gerrold.
Draw up the Company, Where is the Taborour.
Why Timothy.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Here my mad boys, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: But I say where is their women?
Here is and Maudline.
And little Luce with the white legs, and bouncing Barbery.
And freckled Nel; that never failed her Master.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Where be your Ribands maids? swim with your Bodies
And carry it sweetly, and deliverly
And now and then a favour, and a frisk.

sp.speaker: Nel.
sp.l: Let us alone Sir.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Where is the rest of the Music.
Dispersed as you commanded.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Couple then
And see what is wanting; where is the Bavian?
My friend, carry your tail without offence
Or scandal to the Ladies; and be sure
You tumble with audacity, and manhood,
And when you bark do it with judgment.

sp.speaker: Bau.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Here is a woman wanting
We may go whistle: all the fat is in the fire.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: We have,
As learned Authors utter, washed a Tile,
We have been fatuous, and laboured vainly.
This is that scornful piece, that scurvy hilding
That gave her promise faithfully, she would be here,
Cicely the Sempsters daughter:
The next gloves that I give her shall be dog skin;
Nay and she fail me once, you can tell Arcas
She swore by wine, and bread, she would not break.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: An Eel and woman,
A learned Poet says: unless by the tail
And with thy teeth thou hold, will either fail,
In manners this was false position
A fire ill take her; does she flinch now?
What
Shall we determine Sir?

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Nothing,
our business is become a nullity
Yea, and a woeful, and a piteous nullity.
Now when the credit of our Town lay on it,
Now to be frampall, now to piss on the nettle,
Go thy ways, I will remember thee, I will fit thee,

sp.speaker: Daughter.
sp.l: The George alow, came from the South, from
The coast of Barbary a.
And there he met with brave gallants of war
By one, by two, by three, a
Well hailed, well hailed, you jolly gallants,
And whither now are you bound a
O let me have your company till come to the sound a
There was three fools, fell out about an owlet
The one said it was an owl
The other he said nay,
The third he said it was a hawk, and her bells were cut away.
there is a dainty mad woman Master. comes in the Nick as
mad as a march hare: if we can get her dance, we are
made again : I warrant her, she will do the rarest gambols.
A mad woman? we are made Boys.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: And are you mad good woman?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I would be sorry else,
Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I can tell your fortune.
You are a fool: tell ten, I have pozd him: Buzz
Friend you must eat no white bread, if you do
Your teeth will bleed extremely, shall we dance ho?
I know you, you are a Tinker: Sirrah Tinker
Stop no more holes, but what you should.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Dij boni. A Tinker Damsel?

sp.speaker: Daug,
sp.l: Or a Conjurer: raise me a devil now, and let him play
Quipassa, of the bells and bones.

sp.speaker: Sch,
sp.l: Go take her, and fluently persuade her to a peace:

foreign.hi: Et opus exegi, quod nec Iouis ira, nec ignis.

sp.l: Strike up, and lead her in.
Come Last, let us trip it.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I will lead.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Persuasively, and cunningly: away boys,
I hear the horns: give me some
Meditation, and mark your Cue;
Pallas inspire me.

div2.stage: Enter Thes. Pir. Hip. Emil. Arcite: and train.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: This way the Stag took.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Stay, and edify.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Some Country sport, upon my life Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well Sir, go forward, we will edify.
Ladies sit down, we play stay it.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: Thou doughty Duke all hail: all hail sweet Ladies.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: This is a cold beginning.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: If you but favour; our Country pastime made is,
We are a few of those collected here
That ruder Tongues distinguish villager,
And to say verity, and not to fable;
We are a merry rout, or else a rabble
Or company, or by a figure, Choris
That fore thy dignity will dance a Morris.
And I that am the rectifier of all
By title Pedagogus, that let fall
The Birch upon the breeches of the small ones,
And humble with a Ferrule the tall ones,
Do here present this Machine, or this frame,
And dainty Duke, whose doughty dismal fame
From Dis to Dedalus, from post to pillar
Is blown abroad; help me thy poor well willer,
And with thy twinkling eyes, look right and straight
Upon this mighty Morr~~ of mickle weight
Is ~~ now comes in, which being glued together
Makes Morris, and the cause that we came hither.
The body of our sport of no small study
I first appear, though rude, and raw, and muddy,
To speak before thy noble grace, this tenner:
At whose great feet I offer up my penner.
The next the Lord of May, and Lady bright,
The Chambermaid, and Serving-man by night
That seek out silent hanging: Then mine Host
And his fat Spouse, that welcomes to their cost
The galled Traveller, and with a beckoning
Informs the Tapster to inflame the reckoning:
Then the beast eating Clown, and next the fool,
The Bavian with long tail, and eke long tool,
Cum multis aliijs that make a dance,
Say aye, and all shall presently advance.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Aye, aye by any means, dear Dominie.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Produce.
Intrate filij, Come forth, and foot it,

div2.stage: Knock for School. Enter The Dance.

sp.l: Ladies, if we have been merry
And have pleased thee with a derry,
And a derry, and a down
Say the Schoolmaster is no Clown:
Duke, if we have pleased three too
And have done as good Boys should do,
Give us but a tree or twain
For a Maypole, and again
Ere another year run out,
We will make thee laugh and all this rout.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Take twenty Dominie; how does my sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Never so pleased Sir.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: It was an excellent dance, and for a preface
I never heard a better.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Schoolmaster, I thank you, One see them all rewarded.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: And here is something to paint your Pole withal.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Now to our sports again.

sp.speaker: Sch.
sp.l: May the Stag thou huntest stand long,
And thy dogs be swift and strong:
May they kill him without lets,
And the Ladies eat his dowsets: Come we are all made:
Dij Deaeq; omnes, ye have danced rarely wenches.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: About this hour my Cousin gave his faith
To visit me again, and with him bring
Two Swords, and two good Armours; if he fail
He is neither man, nor Soldier; when he left me
I did not think a week could have restored
My lost strength to me, I was grown so low,
And Crestfallen with my wants; I thank thee Arcite,
Thou art yet a fair Foe; and I feel myself
With this refreshing, able once again
To out dure danger: To delay it longer
Would make the world think when it comes to hearing,
That I lay fatting like a Swine, to fight
And not a Soldier: Therefore this blessed morning
Shall be the last; and that Sword he refutes,
If it but hold, I kill him with; it is Justice:
So love, and Fortune for me: O good morrow.

div2.stage: Enter Arcite with Armours and Swords.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Good morrow noble kinsman,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I have put you
To too much pains Sir.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: That too much fair Cousin,
Is but a debt to honour, and my duty.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Would you were so in all Sir; I could wish ye
As kind a kinsman, as you force me find
A beneficial foe, that my embraces
Might thank ye, not my blows.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I shall think either
Well done, a noble recompense.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then I shall quit you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Defy me in these fair terms, and you show
More than a Mistress to me, no more anger
As you love any thing that is honourable;
We were not bred to talk man, when we are armed
And both upon our guards, then let our fury
Like meeting of two tides, fly strongly from us,
And then to whom the birthright of this Beauty
Truly pertains (without obbraidings, scorns,
Despisings of our persons, and such poutings
Fitter for Girls and Schooleboyes) will be seen
And quickly, yours, or mine: wilt please you arm Sir,
Or if you feel yourself not fitting yet
And furnished with your old strength, I will stay Cousin
And every day discourse you into health,
As I am spared, your person I am friends with,
And I could wish I had not said I loved her
Though I had died; But loving such a Lady
And justifying my Love, I must not fly from it.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Arcite, thou art so brave an enemy
That no man but thy Cousin is fit to kill thee,
I am well, and lusty, choose your Arms.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Choose you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Wilt thou exceed in all, or dost thou do it
To make me spare thee?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If you think so Cousin,
You are deceived, for as I am a Soldier.
I will not spare you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: That is well said.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You will find it.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then as I am an honest man and love,
With all the justice of affection
I will pay thee soundly: This I will take.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: That is mine then,
I will arm you first.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Do: pray thee tell me Cousin,
Where gottest thou this good Armour.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: It is the Dukes,
And to say true, I stole it; do I pinch you?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Is it not too heavy?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I have worn a lighter,
But I shall make it serve.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I will buckle it close.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: By any means.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You care not for a Grand guard?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: No, no, we will use no horses, I perceive
You would fain be at that Fight.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am indifferent.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Faith so am I: good Cousin, thrust the buckle
Through far enough.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: My Cask now.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Will you fight bare-armed?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: We shall be the nimbler.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: But use your Gauntlets though; those are of the least,
