Prithee take mine good Cousin.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Thank you Arcite.
How do I look, am I fallen much away?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Faith very little; love has used you kindly.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I will warrant thee, I will strike home.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Do, and spare not;
I will give you cause sweet Cousin.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Now to you Sir,
Methinks this Armour is very like that, Arcite,
Thou worest that day the three Kings fell, but lighter.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: That was a very good one, and that day
I well remember, you outdid me Cousin,
I never saw such valour: when you charged
Upon the left wing of the Enemy,
I spurred hard to come up, and under me
I had a right good horse.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You had indeed
A bright Bay I remember.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Yes but all
Was vainly laboured in me, you outwent me,
Nor could my wishes reach you; yet a little
I did by imitation.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: More by virtue,
You are modest Cousin.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: When I saw you charge first,
Methought I heard a dreadful clap of Thunder
Break from the Troop.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: But still before that flew
The lightning of your valour: Stay a little,
Is not this piece too straight?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: No, no, it is well.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I would have nothing hurt thee but my Sword,
A bruise would be dishonour.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Now I am perfect.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Stand off then.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Take my Sword, I hold it better.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I thank ye: No, keep it, your life lies on it,
Here is one, if it but hold, I ask no more,
For all my hopes: My Cause and honour guard me.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: And me my love: Is there ought else to say?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: This only, and no more: Thou art mine Aunts Son.
And that blood we desire to shed is mutual,
In me, thine, and in thee, mine: My Sword
Is in my hand, and if thou killest me
The gods, and I forgive thee; If there be
A place prepared for those that sleep in honour,
I wish his weary soul, that falls may win it:
Fight bravely Cousin, give me thy noble hand.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Here Palamon: This hand shall never more
Come near thee with such friendship.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I commend thee.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If I fall, curse me, and say I was a coward,
For none but such, dare die in these just Trials,
Once more farewell my Cousin,

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Farewell Arcite.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Lo Cousin, lo, our Folly has undone us.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: This is the Duke, a hunting as I told you,
If we be found, we are wretched, O retire
For honours sake, and safely presently
Into your Bush again; Sir we shall find
Too many hours to die in, gentle Cousin:
If you be seen you perish instantly
For breaking prison, and I, if you reveal me,
For my contempt; Then all the world will scorn us,
And say we had a noble difference,
But base disposers of it.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: No, no, Cousin
I will no more be hidden, nor put off
This great adventure to a second Trial:
I know your cunning, and I know your cause,
He that faints now, shame take him, put thyself
Upon thy present guard.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You are not mad?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Or I will make the advantage of this hour
Mine own, and what to come shall threaten me,
I fear less than my fortune: know weak Cousin
I love Emilia, and in that I will bury
Thee, and all crosses else.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Then come, what can come
Thou shalt know Palamon, I dare as well
Die, as discourse, or sleep: Only this fears me,
The law will have the honour of our ends.
Have at thy life.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Look to thine own well Arcite.

div2.stage: Fight againe. Horns. Enter Theseus, Hipolita, Emilia, Perithous and train.

sp.speaker: Theseus.
sp.l: What ignorant and mad malicious Traitors,
Are you? That against the tenor of my Laws
Are making Battle, thus like Knights appointed,
Without my leave, and Officers of Arms?
By Castor both shall die.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Hold thy word Theseus,
We are certainly both Traitors, both despisers
Of thee, and of thy goodness: I am Palamon
That cannot love thee, he that broke thy Prison,
Think well, what that deserves; and this is Arcite
A bolder Traitor never trod thy ground
A Falser never seemed friend: This is the man
Was begged and banished, this is he contemns thee
And what thou darest do; and in this disguise
Against this own Edict follows thy Sister,
That fortunate bright Star, the fair Emilia
Whose servant, (if there be a right in seeing,
And first bequeathing of the soul to) justly
I am, and which is more, dares think her his.
This treachery like a most trusty Lover,
I called him now to answer; if thou beest
As thou art spoken, great and virtuous,
The true decider of all injuries,
Say, Fight again, and thou shalt see me Theseus
Do such a Justice, thou thyself wilt envy,
Then take my life, I will woo thee to it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O heaven,
What more than man is this!

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I have sworn.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: We seek not
Thy breath of mercy Theseus, It is to me
A thing as soon to die, as thee to say it,
And no more moved: where this man calls me Traitor,
Let me say thus much; if in love be Treason,
In service of so excellent a Beauty,
As I love most, and in that faith will perish,
As I have brought my life here to confirm it,
As I have served her truest, worthiest,
As I dare kill this Cousin, that denies it,
So let me be most Traitor, and ye please me:
For scorning thy Edict Duke, ask that Lady
Why she is fair, and why her eyes command me
Stay here to love her; and if she say Traitor,
I am a villain fit to lie unburied.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Thou shalt have pity of us both, o Theseus,
If unto neither thou show mercy, stop,
(As thou art just) thy noble ear against us,
As thou art valiant; for thy Cousins soul
Whose twelve strong labours crown his memory,
Let us die together, at one instant Duke,
Only a little let him fall before me,
That I may tell my Soul he shall not have her.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: I grant your wish, for to say true, your Cousin
Has ten times more offended, for I gave him
More mercy than you found, Sir, your offences
Being no more than his: None here speak for them
For ere the Sun set, both shall sleep for ever.

sp.speaker: Hipol.
sp.l: Alas the pity, now or never Sister
Speak not to be denied; That face of yours
Will bear the curses else of after ages
For these lost Cousins.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: In my face dear Sister
I find no anger to them ; nor no ruin,
The misadventure of their own eyes kill them;
Yet that I will be woman, and have pity,
My knees shall grow to the ground but I will get mercy.
Help me dear Sister, in a deed so virtuous,
The powers of all women will be with us,
Most royal Brother.

sp.speaker: Hipol.
sp.l: Sir by our tie of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: By your own spotless honour.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: By that faith,
That fair hand, and that honest heart you gave me.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: By that you would have pity in another,
By your own virtues infinite.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: By valour,
By all the chaste nights I have ever pleased you.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: These are strange Conjuring.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Nay then I will in too: By all our friendship Sir, by all our dangers,
By all you love most, wars; and this sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: By that you would have trembled to deny
A blushing Maid.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: By your own eyes: By strength
In which you swore I went beyond all women,
Almost all men, and yet I yielded Theseus.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: To crown all this; By your most noble soul
Which cannot want due mercy, I beg first.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Next hear my prayers.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Last let me entreat Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: For mercy.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Mercy.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Mercy on these Princes.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Ye make my faith reel: Say I felt
Compassion to them both, how would you place it?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Upon their lives: But with their banishment's.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You are a right woman, Sister; you have pity,
But want the understanding where to use it.
If you desire their lives, invent a way
Safer than banishment: Can these two live
And have the agony of love about them ,
And not kill one another? Every day
They would fight about you; hourly bring your honour
In public question with their Swords; Be wise then
And here forget them ; it concerns your credit,
And my oath equally: I have said they die,
Better they fall by the law, than one another.
Bow not my honour.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: O my noble Brother,
That oath was rashly made, and in your anger,
Your reason will not hold it, if such vows
Stand for express will, all the world must perish.
Beside, I have another oath, against yours
Of more authority, I am sure more love,
Not made in passion neither, but good heed.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: What is it Sister?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Urge it home brave Lady.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: That you would never deny me any thing
Fit for my modest suit, and your free granting:
I tie you to your word now, if ye fall in it,
think how you maim your honour;
(For now I am set a begging Sir, I am deaf
To all but your compassion) how, their lives
Might breed the ruin of my name; Opinion,
Shall any thing that loves me perish for me?
That were a cruel wisdom, do men proyne
The straight young Bows that blush with thousand Blossoms
Because they may be rotten? O Duke Theseus
The goodly Mothers that have groaned for these,
And all the longing Maids that ever loved,
If your vow stand, shall curse me and my Beauty,
And in their funeral songs, for these two Cousins
Despise my cruelty, and cry woe worth me,
Till I am nothing but the scorn of women;
For heavens sake save their lives, and banish them .

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: On what conditions?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Swear them never more
To make me their Contention, or to know me,
To tread upon thy Dukedom, and to be
Where ever they shall travel, ever strangers to one another.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I will be cut a pieces
Before I take this oath, forget I love her?
O all ye gods despise me then: Thy Banishment
I not mislike, so we may fairly carry
our Swords, and cause along: else never trifle,
But take our lives Duke, I must love and will,
And for that love, must and dare kill this Cousin
On any piece the earth has.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Will you Arcite
Take these conditions?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: He is a villain then.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: These are men.

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: No, never Duke: It is worse to me than begging
To take my life so basely, though I think
I never shall enjoy her, yet I will preserve
The honour of affection, and die for her,
Make death a Devil.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: What may be done? For now I feel compassion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Let it not fall again Sir.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Say Emilia
If one of them were dead, as one muss, are you
Content to take the other to your husband?
They cannot both enjoy you; They are Princes
As goodly as your own eyes, and as noble
As ever fame yet spoke of; look upon them ,
And if you can love, end this difference,
I give consent, are you content too Princes?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: With all our souls.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: He that she refuses
Must die then.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Any death thou canst invent Duke.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: If I fall from that mouth, I fall with favour,
And Lovers yet unborn shall bless my ashes.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: If she refuse me, yet my grave will wed me,
And Soldiers sing my Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Make choice then.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I cannot Sir, they are both too excellent
For me, a hair shall never fall of these men.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What will become of them ?

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Thus I ordain it,
And by mine honour, once again it stands,
Or both shall die. You shall both to your Country,
And each within this month accompanied
With three fair Knights, appear again in this place,
In which I will plant a Pyramid; and whether
Before us that are here, can force his Cousin
By fair and knightly strength to touch the Pillar,
He shall enjoy her: the other loose his head,
And all his friends; Nor shall he grudge to fall,
Nor think he dies with interest in this Lady:
Will this content ye?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes: here Cousin Arcite
I am friends again, till that hour.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I embrace ye.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Are you content Sister?
Else both miscarry.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Come shake hands again then,
And take heed, as you are Gentlemen, this Quarrel
Sleep till the hour prefixed, and hold your course.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: We dare not fail thee Theseus.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Come, I will give ye
Now usage like to Princes, and to Friends:
When ye return, who wins, I will settle here,
Who looses, yet I will weep upon his Beer.

sp.speaker: Iailor.
sp.l: Hear you no more, was nothing said of me
Concerning the escape of Palamon?
Good Sir remember.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Nothing that I heard,
For I came home before the business
Was fully ended: Yet I might perceive
Ere I departed, a great likelihood
Of both their pardons: For Hipolita,
And faire-eyd Emily, upon their knees
Begged with such hansom pity, that the Duke
Methought stood staggering, whether he should follow
His rash on the or the sweet compassion
Of those two Ladies; and to second them,
That truly noble Prince Perithous
Half his own heart, set in too, that I hope
All shall be well: Neither heard I one question
Of your name, or his scape.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Pray heaven it hold so.

sp.speaker: 2. Fr:
sp.l: Be of good comfort man; I bring you news,
Good news.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: They are welcome,

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: Palamon has cleared you,
And got your pardon, and discovered
How, and by whose means he escaped, which was your Daughters,
Whose pardon is procured too, and the Prisoner
Not to be held ungrateful to her goodness,
Has given a sum of money to her Marriage,
A large one I will assure you.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Ye are a good man
And ever bring good news.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: How was it ended?

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: Why, as it should be; they that never begged
But they prevailed, had their suites fairly granted,
The prisoners have their lives.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: I knew it would be so.

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: But there be new conditions, which you will hear of
At better time.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: I hope they are good.

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: They are honourable,
How good they will prove, I know not.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: It will be known.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Alas Sir, where is your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: O Sir when did you see her?

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: How he looks?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: This morning.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Was she well? was she in health? Sir, when did she sleep?

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: These are strange Questions.

sp.speaker: Iay,
sp.l: I do not think she was very well, for now
You make me mind her, but this very day
I asked her questions, and she answered me
So far from what she was, so childishly.
So sillily, as if she were a fool,
An Innocent, and I was very angry.
But what of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Nothing but my pity; but you must know it, and as good by me
As by an other that less loves her:

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Not right?

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: Not well? ~~ Wooer, No Sir not well.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: it is too true, she is mad.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: Believe you will find it so.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: I half suspected
What you told me: the gods comfort her:
Either this was her love to Palamon,
Or fear of my miscarrying on his scape,
Or both.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: It is likely.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: But why all this haste Sir?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I will tell you quickly. As I late was angling
in the great Lake that lies behind the Palace,
From the far shore, thick set with reeds, and Sedges,
As patiently I was attending sport,
I heard a voice, a shrill one, and attentive
I gave my ear, when I might well perceive
It was one that sung, and by the smallness of it
A boy or woman. I then left my angle
To his own skill, came near, but yet perceived not
Who made the sound; the rushes, and the Reeds
Had so encompassed it: I laid me down
And listened to the words she song, for then
Through a small glade cut by the Fisher men,
I saw it was your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Pray go on Sir?

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: She sung much, but no sense; only I heard her
Repeat this often. Palamon is gone,
Is gone to the wood to gather Mulberries,
I will find him out tomorrow.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Pretty soul.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: His shackles will betray him, he will be taken,
And what shall I do then? I will bring a bevvy,
A hundred black eyed Maids, that love as I do
With Chaplets on their heads of Daffodils,
With cherry-lips, and cheeks of Damask Roses,
And all we will dance an Antique fore the Duke,
And beg his pardon; Then she talked of you Sir;
That you must loose your head tomorrow morning,
And she must gather flowers to bury you,
And see the house made handsome, then she sung
Nothing but Willow, willow, willow, and between
Ever was, Palamon, fair Palamon,
And Palamon, was a tall young man. The place
Was knee deep where she sat; her careless Tresses,
A wreak of bull-rush rounded; about her stuck
Thousand fresh water flowers of several colours.
That methought she appeared like the fair Nymph
That feeds the lake with waters, or as Iris
Newly dropped down from heaven; Rings she made
Of rushes that grew by, and to them spoke
The prettiest posies: Thus our true love's tide,
This you may loose, not me, and many a one:
And then she wept, and sung again, and sighed,
And with the same breath smiled, and kissed her hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: Alas what pity it is?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I made in to her.
She saw me, and straight sought the flood, I saved her,
And set her safe to land: when presently
She slipped away, and to the City made,
With such a cry, and swiftness, that believe me
She left me far behind her; three, or four,
I saw from far off cross her, one of them
I knew to be your brother, where she staid,
And fell, scarce to be got away: I left them with her.
And hither came to tell you: Here they are.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: May you never more enjoy the light, et cetera
Is not this a fine Song?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: O a very fine one.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I can sing twenty more.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I think you can,

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Yes truly can I, I can sing the Broome,
And Bony Robin. Are not you a tailor?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Yes,

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Where is my wedding Gown?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I will bring it tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Do, very rarely, I must be abroad else
To call the Maids, and pay the Minstrels
For I must loose my Maidenhead by cocklight
It will never thrive else.
O fair, O sweet, et cetera

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: You must even take it patiently.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: It is true,

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Good'ev'n, good men, pray did you ever hear
Of one young Palamon?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Yes wench we know him.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Is it not a fine young Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: It is, Love.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: By no mean cross her, she is then distempered
For worse than now she shows.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Yes, he is a fine man.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: O, is he so? you have a Sister.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: But she shall never have him, tell her so,
For a trick that I know, you had best look to her,
For if she see him once, she is gone, she is done,
And undone in an hour. All the young Maids
Of our Town are in love with him, but I laugh at them
And let them all alone, Is it not a wise course?

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: There is at least two hundred now with child by him,
There must be four; yet I keep close for all this,
Close as a Cockle; and all these must be Boys,
He has the trick of it, and at ten years old
They must be all gilt for Musicians,
And sing the wars of Theseus.

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: As ever you heard, but say nothing.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: They come from all parts of the Dukedom to him,
I will warrant ye, he had not so few last night
As twenty to dispatch, he will tickle it up
in two hours, if his hand be in.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: She is lost
Past all cure.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Heaven forbid man.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Come hither, you are a wise man.

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: Does she know him?

sp.speaker: 1. Fr.
sp.l: No, would she did.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: You are master of a Ship?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Where is your Compass?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Set it to the North.
And now direct your course to the wood, where Palamon
Lies longing for me; For the Tackling
Let me alone; Come weigh my hearts, cheerily.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Owgh, owgh, owgh, it is up, the wind is fair, top the
Bowling, out with the maine sail, where is your
Whistle Master?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Let us get her in.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Up to the top Boy.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Where is the Pilot?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: What kennest thou?

sp.speaker: 2. Fr.
sp.l: A fair wood.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Bear for it master: take about:
When Cinthia with her borrowed light, et cetera

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: Yet I may bind those wounds up, that must open
And bleed to death for my sake else; I will choose,
And end their strife: Two such young hansom men
Shall never fall for me, their weeping Mothers,
Following the dead cold ashes of their Sons
Shall never curse my cruelty: Good heaven,
What a sweet face has Arcite? if wise nature
With all her best endowments, all those beauties
She sows into the births of noble bodies,
Were here a mortal woman, and had in her
The coy denials of young Maids, yet doubtless,
She would run mad for this man: what an eye?
Of what a fiery sparkle, and quick sweetness,
Has this young Prince? Here Love himself sits smiling,
Just such another wanton Ganimead,
Set Love a fire with, and enforced the god
Snatch up the goodly Boy, and set him by him
A shining constellation: What a brow,
Of what a spacious Majesty he carries?
Arched like the great eyed Juno's, but far sweeter,
Smoother than Pelops Shoulder? Fame and honour
Methinks from hence, as from a Promontory
Pointed in heaven, should clap their wings, and sing
To all the under world, the Loves, and Fights
Of gods, and such men near them . Palamon,
Is but his foil, to him, a mere dull shadow,
He is swarth, and meagre, of an eye as heavy
As if he had lost his mother; a still temper,
No stirring in him, no alacrity,
Of all this sprightly sharpness, not a smile;
Yet these that we count errors may become him:
Narcissus was a sad Boy, but a heavenly:
O who can find the bent of woman's fancy?
I am a Fool, my reason is lost in me,
I have no choice, and I have lied so lewdly
That women ought to beat me. on my knees
I ask thy pardon: Palamon, thou art alone,
And only beautiful, and these the eyes,
These the bright lamps of beauty, that command
And threaten Love, and what young Maid dare cross them
What a bold gravity, and yet inviting
Has this brown manly face? O Love, this only
From this hour is Complexion: Lie there Arcite,
Thou art a changeling to him, a mere Gypsy.
And this the noble Body: I am sotted,
Utterly lost: My Virgins faith has fled me.
For if my brother but even now had asked me
Whether I loved, I had run mad for Arcite,
Now if my Sister; More for Palamon,
Stand both together: Now, come ask me Brother,
Alas, I know not: ask me now sweet Sister,
I may go look; What a mere child is Fancy,
That having two fair gauds of equal sweetness,
Cannot distinguish, but must cry for both.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: How now Sir?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: From the Noble Duke your Brother
Madam, I bring you news: The Knights are come.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: To end the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Would I might end first:
What sins have I committed, chaste Diana,
That my unspotted youth must now be soiled
With blood of Princes? and my Chastity
Be made the Altar, where the lives of Lovers,
Two greater, and two better never yet
Made mothers joy, must be the sacrifice
To my unhappy Beauty?

div2.stage: Enter Theseus, Hipolita, Perithous and attendants.

sp.speaker: Theseus.
sp.l: Bring them in quickly,
By any means, I long to see them .
Your two contending Lovers are returned,
And with them their fair Knights: Now my fair Sister,
You must love one of them.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I had rather both,
So neither for my sake should fall untimely

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Who saw them ?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I a while.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: From whence come you Sir?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: From the Knights.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Pray speak
You that have seen them, what they are.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: I will Sir,
And truly what I think: Six braver spirits
Than these they have brought, (if we judge by the outside)
I never saw, nor read of: He that stands
in the first place with Arcite, by his seeming
Should be a stout man, by his face a Prince,
(His very looks so say him) his complexion,
Nearer a brown, than black; stern, and yet noble,
Which shows him hardy, fearless, proud of dangers:
The circles of his eyes show fair within him,
And as a heated Lion, so he looks;
His hair hangs long behind him, black and shining
Like Ravens wings: his shoulders broad, and strong,
Armed long and round, and on his Thigh a Sword
Hung by a curious Baldrick; when he frowns
To seal his will with, better on my conscience
Was never Soldiers friend.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Thou hast well described him,

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yet a great deal short
Methinks, of him that is first with Palamon.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Pray speak him friend.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I guess he is a Prince too,
And if it may be, greater; for his show
Has all the ornament of honour in it:
He is somewhat bigger, than the Knight he spoke of,
But of a face far sweeter; His complexion
Is (as a ripe grape) ruddy: he has felt
Without doubt what he fights for, and so apter
To make this cause his own: In his face appears
All the fair hopes of what he undertakes,
And when he is angry, then a settled valour
(Not tainted with extremes) runs through his body,
And guides his arm to brave things: Fear he cannot,
He shows no such soft temper, his head is yellow,
Hard haired, and curled, thick twined like Ivy tops,
Not to undo with thunder; in his face
The livery of the warlike Maid appears,
Pure red, and white, for yet no beard has blessed him.
And in his rolling eyes, sits victory,
As if she ever meant to correct his valour:
His Nose stands high, a Character of honour.
His red lips, after fights, are fit for Ladies.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Must these men die too?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: When he speaks, his tongue
Sounds like a Trumpet; All his lineaments
Are as a man would wish them , strong, and clean,
He wears a well-steeld Axe, the staff of gold,
His age some five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: There is another,
A little man, but of a tough soul, seeming
As great as any: fairer promises
in such a Body, yet I never looked on.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: O, he that is freckle faced?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The same my Lord,
Are they not sweet ones?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes they are well.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Being so few, and well disposed, they show
Great, and fine art in nature, he is white haired,
Not wanton white, but such a manly colour
Next to an aborne, tough, and nimble set,
Which shows an active soul; his arms are brawny
Lined with strong sinews: To the shoulder piece,
Gently they swell, like women new conceived,
Which speaks him prone to labour, never fainting
Under the weight of Arms; stout hearted, still,
But when he stirs, a Tiger; he is gray eyed,
Which yields compassion where he conquers: sharpe
To spy advantages, and where he finds them ,
He is swift to make them his: He does no wrongs,
Nor takes none; he is round faced, and when he smiles
He shows a Lover, when he frowns, a Soldier:
About his head he wears the winners oke,
And in it stuck the favour of his Lady:
His age, some six and thirty. In his hand
He bears a charging Staff, embossed with silver.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Are they all thus?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: They are all the sons of honour.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Now as I have a soul I long to see them
Lady you shall see men fight now.

sp.speaker: Hip
sp.l: I wish it,
But not the cause my Lord; They would show
Bravely about the Titles of two Kingdoms;
It is pity Love should be so tyrannous:
O my soft hearted Sister, what think you?
Weep not, till they weep blood; Wench it must be.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You have steeled them with your Beauty: honoured Friend,
To you I give the Field; pray order it,
Fitting the persons that must use it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Come, I will go visit them : I cannot stay.
Their fame has fired me so; Till they appear,
Good Friend be royal.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: There shall want no bravery.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: Poor wench go weep, for whosoever wins,
Looses a noble Cousin, for thy sins.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Her distraction is more at some time of the Moon,
Than at other some, is it not?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: She is continually in a harmless distemper, sleeps
Little, altogether without appetite, save often drinking,
Dreaming of another world, and a better; and what
Broken piece of matter soever she is about, the name
Palamon lards it, that she farces every business
Withal, fits it to every question; Look where
She comes, you shall perceive her behaviour.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I have forgot it quite; The burden of it, was down
A down a, and penned by no worse man, than
Giraldo, Emilias Schoolmaster; he is as
Fantastical too, as ever he may go upon his legs,
For in the next world will Dido see Palamon, and
Then will she be out of love with Eneas.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: What stuff is here? pore soul.

sp.speaker: Ioy.
sp.l: Even thus all day long.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Now for this Charm, that I told you of, you must
Bring a piece of silver on the tip of your tongue,
Or no ferry: then if it be your chance to come where
The blessed spirits, as there is a sight now; we maids
That have our Livers, perished, cracked to pieces with
Love, we shall come there, and do nothing all day long
But pick flowers with Proserpine, then will I make
Palamon a Nosegay, then let him mark me, ~~ then.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How prettily she is amiss? note her a little further.

sp.speaker: Dau.
sp.l: Faith I will tell you, sometime we go to Barley break,
We of the blessed; alas, it is a sore life they have in the
The other place, such burning, frying, boiling, hissing,
Howling, chattering, cursing, O they have shrowd
Measure, take heed; if one be mad, or hang or
Drown themselves, thither they go , Jupiter bless
Us, and there shall we be put in a Cauldron of
Lead, and Usurers grease, amongst a whole million of
Cutpurses, and there boyle like a Gammon of Bacon
That will never be enough.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How her brain coins?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p:
Lords and Courtiers, that have got maids with
Child, they are in this place, they shall stand in fire up to the
Naval, and in ice up to the heart, and there the offending part
burns, and the deceiving part freezes; in troth a very grievous
punishment, as one would think, for such a Trifle,
believe me one would marry a leprous witch, to be rid of it
I will assure you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How she continues this fancy? It is not an engraffed
Madness, but a most thick, and profound melancholy.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.p:
To hear there a proud Lady, and a proud City
wife, howl together: I were a beast and I would call it good
sport: one cries, o this smoke, another this fire; One cries, o,
that ever I did it behind the arras, and then howls; the other
curses a suing fellow and her garden house.

sp.l: I will be true, my stars, my fate, et cetera

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: What think you of her Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I think she has a perturbed mind, which I cannot minister to.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: Alas, what then?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Understand you, she ever affected any man, ere
She beheld Palamon?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: I was once Sir, in great hope, she had fixed her
Liking on this gentleman my friend.

sp.speaker: Woo.
sp.l: I did think so too, and would account I had a great
Pen-worth on it, to give half my state, that both
She and I at this present stood unfeignedly on the
Same terms.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: That intemperate surfeit of her eye, hath distempered the
Other senses, they may return and settle again to
Execute their preordained faculties, but they are
Now in a most extravagant vagary. This you
Must do, Confine her to a place, where the light
May rather seem to steal in, than be permitted; take
Upon you (young Sir her friend) the name of
Palamon, say you come to eat with her, and to
Commune of Love; this will catch her attention, for
This her mind beats upon; other objects that are
Inserted tween her mind and eye, become the pranks
And friskins of her madness; Sing to her, such green
Songs of Love, as she says Palamon hath sung in
Prison; Come to her, stuck in as sweet flowers, as the
Season is mistress of, and thereto make an addition of
Some other compounded odours, which are grateful to the
Sense: all this shall become Palamon, for Palamon can
Sing, and Palamon is sweet, and every good thing, desire
To eat with her, crave her, drink to her, and still
Among, intermingle your petition of grace and acceptance
Into her favour: Learn what Maids have been her
Companions, and play-pheeres, and let them repair to
her with Palamon in their mouths, and appear with
Tokens, as if they suggested for him, It is a falsehood
She is in, which is with falsehoods to be combated.
This may bring her to eat, to sleep, and reduce what is
Now out of square in her, into their former law, and
Regiment; I have seen it approved, how many times
I know not, but to make the number more, I have
Great hope in this. I will between the passages of
This project, come in with my appliance: Let us
Put it in execution; and hasten the success, which doubt not
Will bring forth comfort.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Now let them enter, and before the gods
Tender their holy prayers: Let the Temples
Burn bright with sacred fires, and the Altars
in hallowed clouds commend their swelling Incense
To those above us: Let no due be wanting,
They have a noble work in hand, will honour
The very powers that love them .

div2.stage: Enter Palamon and Arcite, and their Knights.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sir they enter.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You valiant and strong hearted Enemies
You royal German foes, that this day come
To blow that nearness out that flames between ye;
Lay by your anger for an hour, and dove-like
Before the holy Altars of your helpers
(The all feared gods) bow down your stubborn bodies,
Your ire is more than mortal; So your help be,
And as the gods regard ye, fight with Justice,
I will leave you to your prayers, and betwixt ye
I part my wishes.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Honour crown the worthiest.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: The glass is running now that cannot finish
Till one of us expire: Think you but thus,
That were there ought in me which strove to show
Mine enemy in this business, were it one eye
Against another: Arm oppressed by Arm:
I would destroy the offender, Cuz, I would
Though parcel of myself: Then from this gather
How I should tender you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: I am in labour
To push your name, your ancient love, our kindred
Out of my memory; and in the self same place
To seat something I would confound: So hoist we
The sails, that must these vessels port even where
The heavenly Lymiter pleases.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You speak well;
Before I turn, Let me embrace thee Cousin
This I shall never do again.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: One farewell.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Why let it be so: Farewell Cuz.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Farewell Sir;
Knights, Kinsemen, Lovers, yea my Sacrifices
True worshippers of Mars, whose spirit in you
Expels the seeds of fear, and the apprehension
Which still is farther off it, Go with me
Before the god of our profession: There
Require of him the hearts of Lions, and
The breath of Tigers, yea the fierceness too,
Yea the speed also, to go on, I mean:
Else wish we to be Snails; you know my prize
Must be dragged out of blood, force and great feat
Must put my Garland on where she sticks
The Queen of Flowers: our intercession then
Must be to him that makes the Camp, a Cestron
Brimmed with the blood of men: give me your aid
And bend your spirits towards him.
Thou mighty one, that with thy power hast turned
Green Nepture into purple.
Comets pre-warn, whose havoc in vast Field
Unearthed skulls proclaim, whose breath blows down,
The teeming Ceres foison, who dost pluck
With hand armenypotent from forth blue clouds,
The masoned Turrets, that both makest, and breakest
The stony girths of Cities: me thy pupil,
Youngest follower of thy Drom, instruct this day
With military skill, that to thy lawde
I may advance my Streamer, and by thee,
Be styled the Lord of the day, give me great Mars
Some token of thy pleasure.
sp.stage: Here they fall on their faces as formerly, and there is heard clanging of Armour, with a short Thunder as the burst of a Battle, whereupon they all rise and bow to the Altar.
sp.l: O Great Corrector of enormous times,
Shaker of over-rank States, thou grand decider
Of dusty, and old titles, that healest with blood
The earth when it is sick, and cursed the world
Of the pleurisy of people; I do take
Thy signs auspiciously, and in thy name
To my design; march boldly, let us go .

div2.stage: Exeunt. Enter Palamon and his Knights, with the former observance.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Our stars must glister with new fire, or be
Today extinct; our argument is love,
Which if the goddess of it grant, she gives
Victory too, then blend your spirits with mine,
You, whose free nobleness do make my cause
Your personal hazard; to the goddess Venus
Commend we our proceeding, and implore
Her power unto our party.
Hail Sovereign Queen of secrets, who hast power
To call the fiercest Tyrant from his rage;
And weep unto a Girl; that hast the might
Even with an eye-glance, to choke Marsis Drom
And turn the alarm to whispers, that canst make
A Cripple flourish with his Crutch, and cure him
Before Apollo; that mayst force the King
To be his subjects vassal, and induce
Stale gravity to dance, the pould Bachelor
Whose youth like wanton Boys through Bonfires
Have skipped thy flame, at seventy, thou canst catch
And make him to the scorn of his hoarse throat
Abuse young laies of love; what godlike power
Hast thou not power upon? To Phoebus thou
Addest flames, hotter than his the heavenly fires
Did scorch his mortal Son, thine him; the huntress
All moist and cold, some say began to throw
Her Bow away, and sigh: take to thy grace
Me thy vowed Soldier, who do bear thy yoke
As it were a wreath of Roses, yet is heavier
Than Lead itself, stings more than Nettles;
I have never been foul mouthed against thy law,
Never revealed secret, for I knew none; would not
Had I kenned all that were; I never practised
Upon man's wife, nor would the Libels read
Of liberal wits: I never at great feasts
Sought to betray a Beauty, but have blushed
At simpering Sirs that did: I have been harsh
To large Confessors, and have hotly asked them
If they had Mothers, I had one, a woman,
And women it were they wronged. I knew a man
Of eighty winters, this I told them, who
A Lass of fourteen brided, it was thy power
To put life into dust, the aged Cramp
Had screwed his square foot round,
The Gout had knit his fingers into knots,
Torturing Convulsions from his globie eyes,
Had almost drawn their spheres, that what was life
In him seemed torture: this Anatomy
Had by his young fair pheare a Boy, and I
Believed it was his, for she swore it was,
And who would not believe her? brief I am
To those that prate and have done; no Companion
To those that boast and have not; a defyer
To those that would and cannot; a Rejoycer,
Yea him I do not love, that tells close offices
The foulest way, nor names concealments in
The boldest language, such a one I am,
And vow that lover never yet made sigh
Truer than I. O then most soft sweet goddess
Give me the victory of this question, which
Is true loves merit, and bless me with a sign
Of thy great pleasure.
sp.stage: Here Music is heard, Doves are seene to flutter, they fall againe upon their faces, then on their knees.
sp.l: O thou that from eleven, to ninety raign'st
In mortal bosoms, whose chase is this world
And we in herds thy game; I give thee thanks
For this fair Token, which being laid unto
Mine innocent true heart, arms in assurance
My body to this business: Let us rise
And bow before the goddess: Time comes on.

div2.stage: Exeunt. Still Music of Records. Enter Emilia in white, her hair about her shoulders, a wheaten wreath: One in white holding up her train, her hair stuck with flowers: One before her carrying a silver Hind, in which his conveyed Incense and sweet odours, which being set upon the Altar her maids standing aloofe, she sets fire to it, then they curtsy and kneel.

sp.speaker: Emilia.
sp.l: O sacred, shadowy, cold and constant Queen,
Abandoner of Revels, mate contemplative,
Sweet, solitary, white as chaste, and pure
As wind-fanned Snow, who to thy female knights
Allowest no more blood than will make a blush,
Which is their orders robe. I here thy Priest
Am humbled fore thine Altar, O vouchsafe
With that thy rare green eye, which never yet
Beheld thing maculate, look on thy virgin,
And sacred silver Mistress, lend thine ear
(Which never heard scurrill term, into whose port
Never entered wanton sound,) to my petition
Seasoned with holy fear; This is my last
Of vestal office, I am bride habited,
But maiden hearted, a husband I have pointed,
But do not know him out of two, I should
Choose one, and pray for his success, but I
Am guiltless of election of mine eyes,
Were I to loose one, they are equal precious,
I could doombe neither, that which perished should
Go to it unsentenced: Therefore most modest Queen,
He of the two Pretenders, that best loves me
And has the truest title in it, Let him
Take off my wheaten Garland, or else grant
The file and quality I hold, I may
Continue in thy Band.
sp.stage: Here the Hind vanishes under the Altar: and in the place ascends a Rose Tree, having one Rose upon it.
sp.l: See what our General of Ebbs and Flows
Out from the bowels of her holy Altar
With sacred act advances: But one Rose,
If well inspired, this Battle shall confound
Both these brave Knights, and I a virgin flower
Must grow alone unplucked.
sp.stage: Here is heard a sudden twang of Instruments, and the Rose falls from the Tree.
sp.l: The flower is fallen, the Tree descends: O Mistress
Thou here dischargest me, I shall be gathered,
I think so, but I know not thine own will;
Unclasp thy Mystery: I hope she is pleased,
Her Signs were gracious.

div2.stage: Enter Doctor, Jailer and Wooer, in habit of Palamon.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Has this advice I told you, done any good upon her?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: O very much; The maids that kept her company
Have half persuaded her that I am Palamon; within this
Half hour she came smiling to me, and asked me what I
Would eat, and when I would kiss her: I told her
Presently, and kissed her twice.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: It was well done; twenty times had been far better,
For there the cure lies mainly.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Then she told me
She would watch with me tonight, for well she knew
What hour my fit would take me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Let her do so,
And when your fit comes, fit her home,
And presently.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: She would have me sing.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: You did so?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: It was very ill done then,
You should observe her every way.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Alas
I have no voice Sir, to confirm her that way.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: That is all one, if ye make a noise,
If she entreat again, do any thing,
Lie with her if she ask you.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Hoa there Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Yes in the way of cure.

sp.speaker: Iaylor
sp.l: But first by your leave
In the way of honesty.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: That is but a niceness,
Never cast your child away for honesty;
Cure her first this way, then if she will be honest,
She has the path before her.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Pray bring her in
And let us see how she is.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: I will, and tell her
her Palamon stays for her: But Doctor,
Methinks you are in the wrong still.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Go, go : you Fathers are fine Fools: her honesty?
And we should give her physic till we find that:

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Why, do you think she is not honest Sir?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: How old is she?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: She is eighteen.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: She may be,
But that is all one, it is nothing to our purpose,
What ere her Father says, if you perceive
Her mood inclining that way that I spoke of
Videlicet, the way of flesh, you have me.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Yet very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Please her appetite
And do it home, it cures her ipso facto,
The melancholy humour that infects her.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I am of your mind Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: You will find it so; she comes, pray honour her.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Come, your Love Palamon stays for you child,
And has done this long hour, to visit you.

sp.speaker: Daughter.
sp.l: I thank him for his gentle patience,
He is a kind Gentleman, and I am much bound to him,
Did you never see the horse he gave me?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: How do you like him?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: He is a very fair one.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: You never saw him dance?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I have often.
He dances very finely, very comely,
And for a Jig, come cut and long tail to him,
He turns ye like a Top.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: That is fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: He will dance the Morris twenty mile an hour,
And that will founder the best hobby-horse
(If I have any skill) in all the parish,
And gallops to the turn of Light above,
What think you of this horse?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Having these virtues
I think he might be brought to play at Tennis.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Alas that is nothing.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Can he write and read too.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: A very fair hand, and casts himself the accounts
Of all his hay and provender: That Hostler
Must rise betime that cozens him; you know
The Chestnut Mare the Duke has?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: She is horribly in love with him, poor beast,
But he is like his master coy and scornful.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: What dowry has she?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Some two hundred Bottles,
And twenty strike of Oats, but he will never have her;
He lisps in his neighing able to entice
A Millers Mare,
He will be the death of her.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: What stuff she utters?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Make curtsy, here your love comes.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Pretty soul
How do ye? that is a fine maid, there is a curtsy.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Yours to command in the way of honesty;
How far is it now to the end of the world my Masters?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Why a days Journey wench.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: What shall we do there wench?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Why play at stool ball,
What is there else to do?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I am content
If we shall keep our wedding there.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: It is true
For there I will assure you, we shall find
Some blind Priest for the purpose, that will venture
To marry us, for here they are nice, and foolish;
Besides my father must be hanged tomorrow
And that would be a blot in the business
Are not you Palamon?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Do not you know me?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Yes, but you care not for me; I have nothing
But this pore petticoat, and too corse Smocks.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: That is all one, I will have you.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Will you surely?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Yes by this fair hand will I.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: WE&Htp; will to bed then.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Even when you will.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: O Sir, you would fain be nibbling.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Why do you rub my kiss off?

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: It is a sweet one,
And will perfume me finely against the wedding.
Is not this your Cousin Arcite?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Yes sweetheart,
And I am glad my Cousin Palamon
Has made so fair a choice.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Do you think he will have me?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Yes without doubt.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Do you think so too?

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: We shall have many children: Lord, how you are grown,
My Palamon I hope will grow too finely
Now he is at liberty: Alas poor Chicken
He was kept down with hard meat, and ill lodging
But I will kiss him up again.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: What do you here, you will loose the noblest sight
That ever was seen.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Are they in the Field?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: They are
You bear a charge there too.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: I will away straight
I must even leave you here.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Nay we will go with you,
I will not loose the Fight.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: How did you like her?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: I will warrant you within these three or four days
I will make her right again. You must not from her
But still preserve her in this way.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I will

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Let us get her in.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Come sweet wee'l go to dinner
And then we will play at Cards.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: And shall we kiss too?

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: A hundred times

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: And twenty.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Aye and twenty.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: And then we will sleep together.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Take her offer.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: Yes marry will we.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: But you shall not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Wooer.
sp.l: I will not sweet.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: If you do (Love) I will cry.

div2.stage: Enter Theseus, Hipolita, Emilia, Perithous: and some Attendants, T. Tucke: Curtis.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I will no step further.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Will you loose this sight?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I had rather see a wren hawk at a fly
Than this decision every ; blow that falls
Threats a brave life, each stroke laments
The place whereon it falls, and sounds more like
A Bell, than blade: I will stay here,
It is enough my hearing shall be punished,
With what shall happen, against the which there is
No deafening, but to hear; not taint mine eye
With dread sights, it may shun.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: Sir, my good Lord
Your Sister will no further.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: O she must.
She shall see deeds of honour in their kind,
Which sometime show well pencilled. Nature now
Shall make, and act the Story, the belief
Both sealed with eye, and ear; you must be present,
You are the victors mead, the price, and garland
To crown the Questions title.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Pardon me,
If I were there, I would wink

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: You must be there;
This Trial is as it were in the night, and you
The only star to shine.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I am extinct,
There is but envy in that light, which shows
The one the other: darkness which ever was
The dam of horror, who does stand accursed
Of many mortal Millions, may even now
By casting her black mantle over both
That neither could find other, get herself
Some part of a good name, and many a murther
Set off whereto she is guilty.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You must go .

sp.speaker: Emil,
sp.l: In faith I will not.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Why the knights must kindle
Their valour at your eye: know of this war
You are the Treasure, and must needs be by
To give the Service pay.

sp.speaker: Emil,
sp.l: Sir pardon me,
The title of a kingdom may be tried
Out of itself.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Well, well then, at your pleasure,
Those that remain with you, could wish their office
To any of their Enemies.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Farewell Sister,
I am like to know your husband fore yourself
By some small start of time, he whom the gods
Do of the two know best, I pray them he
Be made your Lot.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Arcite is gently visaged; yet his eye
Is like an Engine bent, or a sharpe weapon
In a soft sheath; mercy, and manly courage
Are bedfellows in his visage: Palamon
Has a most menacing aspect, his brow
Is graved, and seems to bury what it frowns on,
Yet sometime it is not so, but alters to
The quality of his thoughts; long time his eye
Will dwell upon his object. Melancholy
Becomes him nobly; So does Arcites mirth,
But Palamons sadness is a kind of mirth,
So mingled, as if mirth did make him sad,
And sadness, merry; those darker humours that
Stick misbecomingly on others, on them
Live in fair dwelling.
sp.stage: Cornets. Trumpets sound as to a charge.
sp.l: Hark how yon spurs to spirit do incite
The Princes to their proof, Arcite may win me,
And yet may Palamon wound Arcite to
The spoiling of his figure. O what pity
Enough for such a chance; if I were by
I might do hurt, for they would glance their eyes
Toward my Seat, and in that motion might
Omit a ward, or forfeit an offence
Which craved that very time: it is much better
sp.stage: (Cornets. a great cry and noise within crying a Palamon.)
sp.l: I am not there, O better never born
Then minister to such harm, what is the chance?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Cry is of Palamon.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Then he has won: It was ever likely,
He looked all grace and success, and he is
Doubtless the prim'st of men: I pre' thee run
And tell me how it goes.

div2.stage: Shout, and Cornets: Crying a Palamon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Still Palamon.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Run and enquire, poor Servant thou hast lost,
Upon my right side still I wore thy picture,
Palamons on the left, why so, I know not,
I had no end in it; else chance would have it so.
sp.stage: Another cry, and shout within, and Cornets.
sp.l: On the sinister side, the heart lies; Palamon
Had the best boding chance: This burst of clamour
Is sure the end of the Combat.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: They said that Palamon had Arcites body
Within an inch of the Pyramid, that the cry
Was general of Palamon: But anon,
The Assistants made a brave redemption, and
The two bold Tytlers, at this instant are
Hand to hand at it.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Were they metamorphised
Both into one; O why? there were no woman
Worth so composed a Man: their single share,
Their nobleness peculiar to them, gives
The prejudice of disparity values shortness
To any Lady breathing ~~ More exulting?
Palamon still?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nay, now the sound is Arcite.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I pre' thee lay attention to the Cry.
sp.stage: Cornets. a great shout and cry, Arcite, victory.
sp.l: Set both thine ears to the business.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The cry is
Arcite, and victory, hark Arcite, victory,
The Combats consummation is proclaimed
By the wind Instruments.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Half sights saw
That Arcite was no babe: god has lyd, his richness
through him, it could
No more be hid in him, than fire in flax,
Than humble banks can go to law with waters,
That drift winds, force to raging: I did think
Good Palamon would miscarry, yet I knew not
Why I did think so; our reasons are not prophets
When oft our fancies are: They are coming off:
Alas poor Palamon.

div2.stage: Cornets. Enter Theseus, Hipolita, Pirithous, Arcite as victor, and attendants, &c.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Lo, where our Sister is in expectation,
Yet quaking, and unsettled: Fairest Emily,
The gods by their divine arbitrament
Have given you this Knight, he is a good one
As ever struck at head: Give me your hands;
Receive you her, you him, be plighted with
A love that grows, as you decay;

sp.speaker: Arcite.
sp.l: To buy you, I have lost what is dearest to me,
Save what is bought, and yet I purchase cheaply,
As I do rate your value.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: O loved Sister,
He speaks now of as brave a Knight as ere
Did spur a noble Steed: Surely the gods
Would have him die a Bachelor, least his race
Should show in the world too godlike: His behaviour
So charmed me, that methought Alcides was
Each part of him to the all; I have spoke, your Arcite
Did not loose by it; For he that was thus good
Encountered yet his Better, I have heard
Two emulous Philomels, beat the ear of the night
With their contentious throats, now one the higher,
Anon the other, then again the first,
And by and by out breasted, that the sense
Could not be judge between them : So it fared
Good space between these kinsmen; till heavens did
Make hardly one the winner: wear the Garland
With joy that you have won: For the subdued,
Give them our present Justice, since I know
Their lives but pinch them ; Let it here be done:
The Scene's not for our seeing, go we hence,
Right joyful, with some sorrow. Arm your prize,
I know you will not loose her: Hipolita
I see one eye of yours conceives a tear
The which it will deliver.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: Is this winning?
O all you heavenly powers where is you mercy?
But that your wills have said it must be so,
And charge me live to comfort this unfriended,
This miserable Prince, that cuts away
A life more worthy from him, than all women;
I should, and would die too.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Infinite pity
That four such eyes should be so fixed on one
That two must needs be blind for it.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: So it is.

div2.stage: Enter Palamon and his Knights pyniond; Jailer, Executioner &c. Guard.

sp.l: There is many a man alive, that hath out lived
The love of the people, yea in the selfsame state
Stands many a Father with his child; some comfort
We have by so considering: we expire
And not without men's pity. To live still,
Have their good wishes, we prevent
The loathsome misery of age, beguile
The Gout and Rheum, that in lag hours attend
For grey approachers; we come towards the gods
Young, and unwapper'd not, halting under Crimes
Many and stale: that sure shall please the gods
Sooner than such, to give us Nectar with them ,
For we are more clear Spirits. My dear kinsemen.
Whose lives (for this poor comfort) are laid down,
You have sold them too too cheap.

sp.speaker: 1. K.
sp.l: That ending could be
Of more content? over us the victors have
Fortune, whose title is as momentary,
As to us death is certain: A grain of honour
They not overweigh us.

sp.speaker: 2. K.
sp.l: Let us bid farewell;
And with our patience, anger tottering Fortune,
Who at her certainest reels.

sp.speaker: 3. K.
sp.l: Come? Who begins?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Even he that led you to this Banquet, shall
Taste to you all: ah ha my Friend, my Friend,
Your gentle daughter gave me freedom once;
You will see it done now for ever: pray how does she?
I heard she was not well; her kind of ill
gave me some sorrow.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: Sir she is well restored,
And to be married shortly.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: By my short life
I am most glad of it; It is the latest thing
I shall be glad of, prithee tell her so:
Commend me to her, and to piece her portion
Tender her this.

sp.speaker: 1. K.
sp.l: Nay let us be offerers all.

sp.speaker: 2. K.
sp.l: Is it a maid?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Verily I think so,
A right good creature, more to me deserving
Than I can quight or speak of.

sp.speaker: All K.
sp.l: Commend us to her.

sp.speaker: Iaylor.
sp.l: The gods requite you all,
And make her thankful.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Adieu; and let my life be now as short,
As my leave taking.

sp.speaker: 1K.
sp.l: Lead courageous Cousin.

sp.speaker: 1. 2. K.
sp.l: We will follow cheerfully.

div2.stage: A great noise within crying, run, save hold: Enter in hast a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Hold, Hold, O hold, hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: Hold hoa: It is a cursed haste you made
If you have done so quickly: noble Palamon,
The gods will show their glory in a life.
That thou art yet to lead.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Can that be,
When Venus I have said is false? How do things fare?

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: Arise great Sir, and give the tidings ear
That are most early sweet, and bitter.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What
Hath waked us from our dream?

sp.speaker: Pir.
sp.l: List then: your Cousin
Mounted upon a Steed that Emily
Did first bestow on him, a black one, owing
Not a hair worth of white, which some will say
Weakens his price, and many will not buy
His goodness with this note: Which superstition
Here finds allowance: on this horse is Arcite
Trotting the stones of Athens, which the Calkins
Did rather tell, than trample; for the horse
Would make his length a mile, if it pleased his Rider
To put pride in him: as he thus went counting
The flinty pavement, dancing as it were to the Music
His own hooves made; (for as they say from iron
Came Musics origin) what envious Flint,
Cold as old Saturn, and like him possessed
With fire malevolent, darted a Spark
Or what fierce sulphur else, to this end made,
I comment not; the hot horse, hot as fire
Took Toy at this, and fell to what disorder
His power could give his will, bounds, comes on end,
Forgets school doing, being therein trained,
And of kind mannadge, pig-like he whines
At the sharpe Rowel, which he frets at rather
Than any jot obeys; seeks all foul means
Of boisterous and rough Iadrie, to dis-seate
His Lord, that kept it bravely: when nought served,
When neither Curb would crack, girth break nor differing plunges
Dis-roote his Rider whence he grew, but that
He kept him tween his legs, on his hind hooves
on end he stands
That Arcites legs being higher than his head
Seemed with strange art to hang: His victors wreath
Even then fell off his head: and presently
Backward the Jade comes over, and his full poise
Becomes the Riders load: yet is he living,
But such a vessel it is, that floats but for
The surge that next approaches: he much desires
To have some speech with you: Lo he appears.

div2.stage: Enter Theseus, Hipolita, Emilia, Arcite, in a chair.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: O miserable end of our alliance
The gods are mighty Arcite, if thy heart,
Thy worthy, manly heart be yet unbroken:
Give me thy last words, I am Palamon,
One that yet loves thee dying.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Take Emilia
And with her, all the worlds joy: Reach thy hand,
Farewell: I have told my last hour; I was false,
Yet never treacherous: Forgive me Cousin:
One kiss from fair Emilia: It is done:
Take her: I die.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Thy brave soul seek Elizium.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.l: I will close thine eyes, Prince; Blessed souls be with thee
Thou art a right good man, and while I live,
This day I give to tears.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And I to honour.

sp.speaker: These.
sp.l: In this place first you fought: even very here
I sundered you, acknowledge to the gods
Our thanks that you are living:
His part is played, and though it were too short
He did it well: your day is lengthened, and,
The blissful dew of heaven does arouse you.
The powerful Venus, well hath graced her Altar,
And given you your love: our Master Mars
Hast vouched his Oracle, and to Arcite gave
The grace of the Contention: So the Deities
Have showed due justice: Bear this hence.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: O Cousin,
That we should things desire, which do cost us
The loss of our desire; That nought could buy
Dear love, but loss of dear love.

sp.speaker: Thes.
sp.l: Never Fortune
Did play a subtler Game: The conquered triumphs,
The victor has the Loss: yet in the passage,
The gods have been most equal: Palamon,
Your kinsman hath confessed the right of the Lady
Did lie in you, for you first saw her, and
Even then proclaimed your fancy: He restored her
As your stolen Jewel, and desired your spirit
To send him hence forgiven; The gods my justice
Take from my hand, and they themselves become
The Executioners: Lead your Lady off;
And call your Lovers from the stage of death,
Whom I adopt my Friends. A day or two
Let us look sadly, and give grace unto
The Funeral of Arcite, in whose end
The visages of Bridegrooms we will put on
And smile with Palamon; for whom an hour,
But one hour since, I was as dearly sorry,
As glad of Arcite: and am now as glad,
As for him sorry. O you heavenly Charmers,
What things you make of us? For what we lack
We laugh, for what we have, are sorry still,
Are children in some kind. Let us be thankful
For that which is, and with you leave dispute
That are above our question: Let us go off,
And bear us like the time.

sp.speaker: EPILOGVE.
sp.l: I would now ask ye how ye like the Play,
But as it is with School Boys, cannot say,
I am cruel fearful: pray yet stay a while,
And let me look upon ye: No man smile?
Then it goes hard I see; He that has
Loved a young handsome wench then, show his face:
It is strange if none be here, and if he will
Against his Conscience let him hiss, and kill
Our Market: It is in vain, I see to stay ye,
Have at the worst can come, then; Now what say ye?
And yet mistake me not: I am not bold
We have no such cause. If the tale we have told
(For it is no other) any way content ye)
(For to that honest purpose it was meant ye)
We have our end; and ye shall have ere long
I dare say many a better, to prolong
Your old loves to us: we, and all our might,
Rest at your service, Gentlemen, good night.
